## H.P.R.
 
 <i>abbr.</i> homestead pre-emptive right [(hist.)]

>  <b>CRAWFORD</b> Although many runholders came to regard the land they leased as their own, their occupancy was intended to be only a temporary using of waste land until it was required for closer settlement. Anyone - the runholder included - could buy the freehold of all or any part of a run at any time to establish a farm. However, some protection for runholders was essential, for they could not be expected to improve their runs if the land and improvements were in danger of being freeholded without warning by an outside buyer. Runholders were able to register with the Provincial Council improvements such as buildings, plantations, fencing, and yards, for which they were granted [246] an improvement pre-emptive right (i.P.R.) covering fifty acres of land surrounding the improvement. A homestead pre-emptive right (H.P.R.), which afforded protection for 250 acres, could also be registered. ... One H.P.R. could be taken out for each property and it was only businesslike that each runholder should use this right to secure 250 acres around his homestead against purchase by an outsider. An H.P.R. was initially intended to cover the owner's or manager's home, but, in the case of runs of over 5,000 acres, could be extended to cover an outstation. <i>(1981,Station Years</i>) [NOTES: [ca1878]]

>  The term `hack' as understood in this country is not at all to be conflicted with the same term as applied elsewhere to horse racing under that category. A hack in New Zealand is a horse that has not won a certain amount of moneys [sic], and so it is quite possible for the Derby favorite of the year, or the New Zealand Cup favorite to be a hack. <i>(May 4, 1907,NZ Truth,98/2/3</i>) [NOTES: (hist.)]

## Habitual Criminal
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>BURTON</b> This is an indeterminate sentence, and can only be given to a man who has been declared an Habitual Criminal. ... Unless the `Act' is lifted from him by a judge of the Supreme Court it will continue in force for the rest of his life. Among convicts this particular sentence is is known as the `dog collar' for obvious reasons. <i>(1945,in Prison,133</i>)

>  GLOSSARY OF TECHNiCAL TERMS: A boobhead is a prisoner; a screw is a warder; a topper is a toady or an informer. The Act or the Collar - The Habitual Criminals Act, under which persons declared habitual criminals can have their sentences increased by the Prisons Board for offences against prison discipline during their incarceration. <i>(Nov 1950,Here & Now,14</i>) [NOTES: (ian Hamilton `NZd's Last Flogging')]

>  <b>MacKENZiE</b> in 1953 i made a study ... of New Zealand's habitual criminals. These 520 people ... had received the accolade of New Zealand criminality ... in prison language they had been given the `collar', the `key', the Kathleen Mavourneen sentence - `it may be for years and it may be for ever'. ... The unfortunate recipients of the new title `Habitual Criminal' would serve a head sentence of Hard Labour to be followed by an unspecified period of imprisonment which could last until death. <i>(1980,While We Have Prisons,9</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called <i>para</i>[as-acute] <i> paraua</i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale,<i> mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale, <i> tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, <i> mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes. <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202 fn</i>)

>  <b>SAVAGE</b> Hurramy ... Come here. <i>(1807,Some Account of NZ,76</i>)

>  <b>NiCHOLAS</b> The moment we were preceived, one of their women ... repeatedly cried out ... in a loud and shrill voice, haromai, haromai, haromai, (come hither,) the customary salutation of friendship and hospitality. <i>ibid.</i> 2/330 Come hither Haromai <i>(1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/127</i>)

>  <b>183</b> `Hairemi, hairemi, Atua!' - Come hither, come hither, thou God! <i>(1819,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,1932</i>)

Heromai, or `Come hither', is the salutation of peace and friendship. Where this word is not pronounced on the approach of the stranger the feelings of the people are not favourable towards him. <i>(Aug 5, 1820,Journal,134,1957 ed.</i>)

>  <b>McCRAE</b> ... we were received with the greatest hospitality by his people who waving their mats called out to us - `Haromai, Haromi[sic],' their welcome to strangers which means literally `Come to us' `Come to us'. <i>(1820,Journal,20,1928 ed.</i>)

>  come here - e|rromai [haere mai] <i>(1826,Boultbee Journal,112,1986 ed.</i>) [NOTES: SEE ALSO 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 284]

>  <b>McNAB</b> A number of natives collected at the place of our landing, and received us with the herremi, or `salutations of friendship' (the principal of these are their joining noses). <i>(1908,Historical Records,1/689</i>) [NOTES: >1829 Mar 2 Atkins's Narrative in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/689]

>  <b>WiLLiAMS</b> [The natives] were very glad to see us and gave us the usual welcome, haere mai, haere mai, Come, Come. <i>(Jan 13, 1832,Journal,216,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MARKHAM</b> Heremi checonay [Haere mai ki konei] Come hither; ... <i>(1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),50,1963 ed.</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> i ... proceeded to the village with the inhabitants ... uttering, with deafening shouts, `Airemai [e-acute]! airemai [e-acute]!' - welcome! welcome! ... accompanied by a ... waving of mats, and other expressions of applause, which are so liberally bestowed by these islanders, on those whom they may choose to honour. <i>ibid.</i> 1/160 As soon as friends ere espied ... mats were waved, the `airemai,' [e-acute] or wel-[161]come, was shouted ... <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),1/76</i>)

>  ... were met by a large body of Mauries ... who first sang the iremi. <i>(Jun 1840,Journal of Ensign Best,225,1966 ed.</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> As we approached the village, a number of stout natives, wholly denuded of dress, rushed forward in a tumultuous manner to meet us, hallooing and roaring to the utmost extent of their well-practised lungs, a welcome, (airamai!) <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/83</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> [We] were received [by the Ngati Whakaue] ... with the salutation `Nau mai, nau mai!' which is here the term of welcome instead of the `Haere mai', of the other parts of the country. <i>(1959,Early Travellers,152</i>) [NOTES: 1847 Johnson Notes from Journal in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 152]

>  <b>MANiNG</b> Then, as the boat came nearer, another burst of haere mai! But unaccustomed as i was then to the Maori salute, i disliked the sound. <i>ibid.</i> (ii) 21 The boat darts on; she touches ... a steep rock; the `haere mai' has subsided; six or seven `personages' ... come gravely to meet me as i land. <i>(1863,Old New Zealand,(i)16</i>)

>  <b>HUNT</b> Here we stopped, and the canoes were drawn up in front of the pa, amidst much tangi-ing, and shouts of `Haeremai, haeremai, haeremai!' - the usual amount of shaking hands and rubbing noses being over, a long korero, or talk, ensued. <i>(1866,Chatham islands,17</i>)

>  [spg ?jocular] ... old Matakatea would not let me go ... At last he said `Haere marie' & away we came. <i>(Mar 1, 1867,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/232,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

>  <b>THATCHER</b> Ropata's whare soon they spied, `Tenakoe!' the deputation cried, `Haeremai, Pakeha!' Ropata replied, When they got to the Ohinemuri. <i>(1869,Wit and Humour: Local Songs...,33</i>) [NOTES: The Ohinemuri Deputation]

>  <b>CAMPBELL</b> Had we been Maoris of course we should there and then have also squatted down and rubbed noses. Hereafter i will explain why at such meetings the natives do not jump up and say how glad they are to see you, but welcome you in woe-begone `Haere mai's', squatting down and rubbing the lugubrious nose until the spectacle is anything but pleasant to look at. <i>ibid.</i> 4/4/267 The `haeremais' and `tautemais' - `come' - `come to my arms' of some blanketed figures standing near some huts seemed to exercise the most uncontrollable influence over my friends, ... <i>(1881,Poenamo,3/2/142</i>)

>  <b>RENWiCK</b> Haire mai ho! 'tis the welcome song/ Rings far on the summer air. <i>(1883,Betrayed,34</i>)

## haere ra
 
 <i>exclam.</i> Farewell (to one departing) [Maori haere r&amacr.(phs popularised as the title of a well-known Maori song) (Williams: haere v. come; go, depart: ra av. there, yonder; or a particle denoting distance from the speaker), said to a person leaving, goodbye, farewell.

>  <b>CAMPBELL</b> You can see a good many bundles of blankets and black top-knots scattered over the beach, all immovable. That is the native fashion of bidding goodbye, ... [34] But meanwhile we must `haere' along or we shall never get clear of Herekino. <i>(1881,Poenamo,33</i>)

>  <b>HYDE</b> `Haere ra, i'm going to Napier to get my divorce.' You never hear such a korero. They don't like a divorce. <i>(1938,Nor the Years Condemn,169</i>)

>  haeremai, as this is included in the Dictionary, haerera also should be included, the former being the response to the latter. <i>ibid.</i> 55/151 haerera,term of farewell, said by the one who stays to the one who goes: ra, an indefinite `yonder.' The reply by the departer is: e noho (lit. sit still), or hei konei ra (for you this place).<i>ibid.</i> 151 haerera, term of farewell, said by the one who stays to the one who goes: ra, an indefinite `yonder.' The reply by the departer is: e noho (lit. sit still), or hei konei ra (for you this place). <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

>  <b>ZiMMERMAN</b> ... the crowd came with me, and instead of saying goodby or cheer-o, they said Haere ra' and i liked them for it, for it means, `Go, then.' <i>(1946,Where the People Sing,42</i>)

>  haere ra: farewell. <i>(1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173</i>)

## hahunga
 
 <i>n.</i> ceremony of exhuming and scraping bones of the dead. [See also lifting the bones]

>  <b>OPPENHEiM</b> [Hdg] The Display of the Bones (Hahunga). ibid 70 in the northern tradition the time lapse between primary burial and Hahunga could be anything from a few months to several years. <i>(1973,Maori Death Customs,64</i>)

>  <b>WiLLiAMS</b> Tekoke and most of the natives of the settlement had left to attend a Hahunga at Taeamai. ... [131 May 30] ... two messengers arrived from Waimate ... to request our attendance at the Ha'hunga ... <i>ibid.</i> 244 The Chiefs Hiamoe and Pukututu came from the Kauakaua to request some of us to go up to attend the Hahunga there, the feast which takes place at the removal of the bones of the dead. <i>(May 23, 1828,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,130,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>YATE</b> Hahunga, a grand annual feast ... No further notice is taken of the deceased till the Hahunga, a grand annual feast; when the [138] bones of all belonging to several united tribes are taken down, and removed to their last resting-place, in or near the sacred grove. <i>(1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),137</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

>  <b>SHORTLAND</b> A very curious ceremony, called hahunga, takes place when the skulls of the dead are exhibited to their living relations before being finally deposited in the secret family vault. <i>(1856,Traditions & Superstitions,147</i>)

>  Hahunga - A hahunga was a funeral ceremony, at which the natives usually assembled in great numbers, and during which `baked meats' were disposed of ... <i>(1863,Old New Zealand,236,(Auckland edn) ed.</i>)

>  The Exhumation, or hahunga, - i.e., cleaning of the bones, - sometimes took place a year after death. <i>(1869,TrNZi,1/iii/20</i>) [NOTES: (Colenso Maori races)]

>  <b>TiNNE</b> The most ... interesting ceremonial ... was a `huhunga,' or bone-scraping, ... <i>(1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,66</i>)

>  ... the hahunga, a feast attending the ceremonial raising of a chief's bones ... <i>(1895,TrNZi,27/611</i>)

>  <b>KEENE</b> Hahunga: ceremony of exhuming and scraping bones of the dead. <i>(1963,O Te Raki,190</i>)

>  For his information, the hahunga (exhumation) did not occur on the same night of the burial or interment, as he did to his grandmother... <i>(Apr 19, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,02</i>)

## hairy-arsed learner
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  hairy-arsed learner: A man who has probably shorn a hundred thousand sheep in his day but whose skill has been much reduced by age or infirmity. <i>(1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/25</i>) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]



## haka
 
 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>NiCHOLAS</b> To dance Sha[acute]kka <i>(1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/340</i>)

>  <b>WiLLiAMS</b> [spg 'hakaring] As soon as night had closed in the natives began to dance and after 'hakaring for some time there was a general firing round, many fired ball. <i>(Mar 23, 1828,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,115,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> We had not been in long, before one of the chiefs called on the girls to come and haka to the strangers, and in a few minutes a number of the prettiest young girls ... were seated in a circle in very shallow water ... They sang us a wild song ... [ed fn] Short for haka taparahi, a term covering all dances and action songs ... <i>(1959,Early Travellers,444</i>) [NOTES: 1864 Dec Meade Ride through Disturbed Districts in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 444]



 
 <i>n.</i> the word suggests today violent and noisy posture-dance (cf. A. 1896)

>  `general term for a posture-dance; dance with song and action; usually supposed to mean a War-dance; but the real earth-shaking and nerve-shattering war-dance is peruperu, with its savage gesturing, eye-glaring, and cries demoniac, the savagest looking of which may be in pure fun and intended as hearty welcome. Both vowels must be short ...' - <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words]



 
 <i>n.</i> [attrib.]

>  <b>FiNLAYSON</b> it was a grand welcome; although the haka dancers unexpectedly faced the wrong way for the movie camera man ... <i>(1943,Brown Man's Burden,88,1973 ed.</i>) [NOTES: `Sweet Beulah Land']

>  The entire country, Pakeha as well as Maori, had haka fever. <i>(Mar 21, 2006,Dominion Post,B4</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> in a debased form, often with meaningless Maori-looking words, and, esp. in Otago, English words and cries, a school or team form of noisy encouragement, or rally; often called `the school haka'. [ca 1900 -->eg Boomeranga! Boomeranga! ow-wow-wow!. -->(Apparently used in Australia in the same sense: -->May 1950 Austr. newsreel (West Austr; `Head of the River' Boat-race) `... college boys giving their war cries and hakas']

>  <b>McLiNTOCK</b> Perhaps the most useful and expressive of our loans from the Maori is mana, reputation, honour, etc. Another is haka, now becoming well known wherever our football teams go. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679</i>) [NOTES: (Wall NZ Speech)]

>  <b>TURNER</b> The word haka `a Maori war dance' has become common as friendly hakas usually introduce a football match and haka parties associated with students' capping processions fix it in the minds of the leading citizens of tomorrow. <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,169</i>)

>  1st XV play Wellington Old Boys. ... We have to know School haka, house haka, 1st XV, house XV, ... by heart. <i>(1972,islands,1/15</i>) [NOTES: Henderson (Freedom's Ramparts)]

>  Nor should we left-wing trendy feminist pooftah intellectuals forget that the ritual haka at the start of a rugby game antedates by many decades the perfunctory `kia ora' with which we nowadays preface our performance. <i>(Nov 8, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8</i>)

>  Everywhere you look, and for any reason they can think of, there's some people doing the "hukka", as it's now called. Given our love of this ritual, i'm surprised we don't have a national hukka tournament, from which a national team would be chosen. They would represent us at international competitions dressed in traditional apparel and be called the All Flax. <i>(Oct 10, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B15</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HOLMES</b> Threatening hakas by spear-toting Fijian warriors. <i>(1977,Best of Homespun,36</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a dance; a song (accompanying a dance) [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  <b>HARSANT</b> Following the big feast there were haka, songs, poi dances and stick games, until it was time for the evening meal. <i>(1979,They Called Me Te Maari,53</i>)

>  <b>BUCK</b> <i>(1949,Coming of the Maori, The,243</i>)

>  <b>ASHTON-WARNER</b> <i>(1958,Spinster,197</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,224</i>)

>  [The Duke of York] was given an uproarious welcome by [Otago Univ.] undergraduates, who performed the vigorous `Haka' and sang the University song <i>(Mar 18, 1927,Glasgow Herald,13</i>)

>  And the parlour pianist could rattle off a spectacular solo called "The Maori Haka Rondoletto". <i>(Oct 19, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),22</i>)

>  A million maggots shall do a haka / on the carcase of a stud bull. <i>(Apr 6, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> Someone starts the school haka. <i>(1983,Dominion Sunday Times,149</i>)

>  The translated [Te Rauparaha] haka goes like this: "it is death, it is death / it is life, it is life / it is death, it is death / it is life, it is life / This is the hairy person / Who caused the sun to shine again for me / Up the ladder, up the ladder / Up to the top / The sun shines!" <i>(Apr 10, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48</i>)

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> to kick up a fuss

>  To do the haka about some culturally correct position ... They should possibly be ignoring it and getting on with encouraging our families and parents [to immunise]. <i>(Oct 15, 2004,Dominion Post,A9</i>)

## hakari
 
 <i>n.</i> the feast after a ceremonial funeral or other important occasion; a feast, f. Maori: Williams: [Maori h&amacr.kari] [[Ma. <b>hakari</b> feast] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 42.]

>  The well-organised reunion concluded on Sunday with a memorial service and hakari. <i>(Apr 21, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,3</i>)

>  <b>CRUiSE</b> One of the gentlemen ... was present at the shackerie, or harvest home (if it may be so called), of Shungie's people. it was celebrated in a wood, where a square space had been cleared of trees, in the centre of which three very tall posts, driven into the ground in the form of a triangle, supported an immense pile of baskets of koomeras. <i>(Apr 21, 1820,Journal,83,1957 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1820 Apr 21 in 1823 Cruise Journal (1957) 83]

>  <b>LEE & KENDALL</b> A'karii, s. A feast, where large presents of fish, potatoes, fern-root ... are brought by the visitors to the party visited. <i>(1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,133</i>)

>  <b>YATE</b> There is another feast given at another period of the year, called the Hakari; but it is totally different from the Hahunga; the visiters[sic] bringing the cooked food, and receiving from their hosts an immense quantity, piled up in the form of a pyramid, eighty feet high, and twenty feet square at the base. <i>(1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),139</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> An entertainment, or hakari [a2-acute], was afterwards given by the parents of either party, ... <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),1/188</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> ... and confesses that the angry war-speech and wildly excitingdance is attended with infinitely less satisfaction than that of an argument in driving a bargain in commerce and the hakari (dance) of the harvest-home. <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/4</i>)

>  <b>ROSS</b> [fn] These feasts, which are called `Hakari' or feasts of peace, are now of but rare occurrence, and not always devoted to their original purpose. <i>(1841,Voyage of Discovery to North Pacific Ocean,2/99</i>)

>  <b>DiEFFENBACH</b> Hakari - a feast of peace where presents of fish are brought by the visitors; ... <i>(1843,Travels in NZ,2/361</i>)

>  <b>THOMSON</b> The New Zealanders had another feast, called the hakari, very different from the hahunga. The hakari was a banquet given by nations to each other, ... Previously to the arrival of the guests the food was piled either on the ground or on wooden scaffolds. Such erections were sqare pyramidal towers having an elevation of fifty feet, or ranges of six feet high, extending from half a mile to two miles. There were several compartments in these receptacles for food; each being filled up with sweet potatoes, taros, maize, fern root, potted birds, dried fish, karaka berries, ... <i>(1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/189</i>)

>  in afn. ... rode down to Mangaone ...[sic] where there was said to be a great hakari (feast) going on, but it had not begun... in afn. [sic] caught my poney [sic] & rode down to Mangaone ... where there was said to be a great hakari (feast) going on ... <i>(Apr 17, 1863,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/34,1960 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

>  <b>BULLER</b> A HAKARi, OR FEAST. [heading] <i>(1878,Forty Years in NZ,89</i>)

>  <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society</i>) [NOTES: ANDERSEN]

## hake
 
 <i>n.</i> [Cf Doug Gray's article on naming of new things on Cook's Voyages, see also Cloudy Bay cod, English hake, (southern) kingfish. Take in Young's note following:]

>  Another matter touching on the recurring annoyance of vernacular names is that up till 1891 <i>Lotella rhacinus</i> was universally accepted as the hake: then, in 1912, Waite, for no apparent reason, transfers this name to <i>Merluccius gayi</i>, although he admits that the records of these fish were hopelessly mixed on the expedition. ... <i>(1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/370</i>) [NOTES: (Young)]

>  <b>HUTTON</b> <i>Lotella rhacinus</i>= hake, with a note on its relationship to Physiculus bacchus. He calls Gadus australis (Hutton) the `haddock.' <i>(1872,Catalogue of NZ Fishes,116</i>)

>  Records <i>Lotella rhacinus</i> from the Chatham islands. <i>(1872,TrNZi,5/266</i>)

>  <i>Gadus australis</i> = haddock. <i>(1877,TrNZi,10/326</i>) [NOTES: P. Thomson]

>  <b>SHERRiN</b> <i>Lotella rhacinus</i> = hake. <i>Pseudophycis brevissculu</i>s = whiting. Reports <i>Lotella rhacinus</i> from the Chathams, after Hutton. <i>(1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,17</i>)

>  <i>Pseudophycis</i> sp. Noted as common, with remarks on variation of size and fins. Specimens sent to Hector. The spirit specimen (1) in the Museum is probably one of these, as it is labelled with Sandager's name. <i>(1887,TrNZi,20/131</i>)

>  Hake = <i>Lotella rhacinus</i>. <i>ibid.</i> 210 in report from Cape Maria van Diemen, where the terms `blue-fish' and `rock-cod' (<i>Parapercis</i>) are used together , i suspect that the former were specimens of <i>Physiculus rhacinus</i>, and this would extend the range a little. <i>(1891,TrNZi,24/21</i>) [NOTES: G. M . Thomson]

>  This is where the confusion starts. He records <i>Merluccius gayi</i> (Guichenot)-syn. for <i>Merlus gayi</i> (Guich.) and <i>Gadus australis</i> (Hutton) - as the `hake,' and makes no independent record for <i>Physiculus rhacinus</i>, but admits that the records of the two fishes were in a state of hopeless confusion, thus tacitly admitting that specimens of both were recorded under the same name. LiTERATURE WiTH A SUMMARY OF THE DATA iN EACH CASE. <i>(1912,Records of the Canterbury Museum,1(2):182</i>) [NOTES: E. R. Waite]

## hakoke
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Extinct birds ... Laughing Owl <i>Sceloglaux albifacies</i> (GRAY, 1844) OTHER NAMES: Whekau, hakoke (North island),rock owl. The `doleful shrieks' of the laughing owl, which varied seasonally, were heard incessantly on rainy nights. Apparently it was easily kept in captivity, and reports say that it cooeyed in the evening, yelped like a young dog and mewed and chuckled. ... ## hakuwai
 
 <i>n.</i> A Maori legendary bird, said to be heard at night but never seen. (Suggested originals include frigate bird, Haast's eagle; the most probable being Miskelly below, i.e. NZ snipe in display flights.) See also hokioi. [19?? Miskelly in Notornis 34 get cit]

>  Many legends are associated with the mythical bird "hokioi"... in the South and in some parts of the North island it is identical, apparently, with the "hakuwai" which has seven joints in its wing, lives in the sky, and presages trouble... "its cry was Hokioi! Hokioi! Hu!" The last word represented the whizzing sound made by the bird in flight. <i>(Sep 11, 1912,Otago Witness,76</i>)

>  <b>DEMPSEY</b> The Mysterious Ha-ka-wai Bird [heading] No-one has ever seen it, no-one knows what it is like. Mutton-birders who have heard the strange sound of its passing over the islands at night speak of the ha-ka-wai bird. A swish of wings close overhead, a sound like the rattle of chains when a boat lets the anchor down, again the sound of wingbeats and the cry floating earthward from the heavens, Ha-ka-wai! Ha-ka-wai! in a drawn-out singsong with accent on the first and last syllables. <i>(1964,Little World of Stewart island,61</i>)

>  A strange bird in Maori eyes is the hakuai of the off-shore islands in the far south. ... Whole families go mutton-birding ... At night the fowlers gather round their camp-fires, and old songs are sung ... and ghost-stories retold. And in the darkness sometimes they hear the ghost-bird screaming its `Haku-ai, haku-ai, Ooh!' and then a hair-raising swoosh of great wings ... This bird, called the `hakuai' from its call, is spoken of as a spirit. ... The mystery of the hakuai may be dispelled by assuming it to be ... the frigate-bird (Fregata aquila). <i>(1906,TrNZi,38/340</i>)

>  The Maori word <i>hakuwai</i> (or <i>hakawai</i> or <i>hakuai</i>, or any of at least five other variant spellings, including the European <i>harkowhy</i>) was defined by Williams in his <i>Maori Dictionary</i> as 'an extinct bird heard at night'. <i>(Aug 2000,NZWords,No. 4: 5</i>)

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> it is a moot point whether the name <i>hakuwai</i> was derived from <i>hokioi</i>.. or whether <i>hokioi</i> has been adopted., as an imperfect rendition of <i>hakuwai</i>, to provide a name for the eagle legend. <i>(1989,Prodigious Birds,91</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> He heard the harkowhy up in Canaan on the Takaka Hill, the ghost-bird never seen but many times heard by muttonbirders and the odd fisherman in the mist and fog in Stewart island, crying like a chain rattling. <i>(1983,Down from Marble Mountain,142</i>)

>  <b>WiLSON</b> The Hakawai is the Maori mystery bird. <i>ibid.</i> 92 One of the party who had heard it before on several occasions called "Listen, there's the Hakawai". <i>(1979,Titi Heritage,91</i>)

>  The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five bob, and most familiar of all a dollar, ... The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull, half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and two-and-a-buck. in the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The florin seems to have had fewer English nicknames, only two bob being recorded as being in use in New Zealand. <i>(Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15</i>)

## half savage
 
 <i>n.</i> [aka half-savage]

>  Coming to a country where there were no legal means of enforcing such rights, when objected to, did the first settlers expect to walk into every acre without opposition? or, if not, were the Company to provide an army to give possession by force? or, if not that, did they believe that the cupidity of the half-savage was not inextinguishable by feeding it, and that additional gifts and presents would not be building a barrier to keep them from their lands? <i>(Jun 3, 1843,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,258</i>)

>  it may have suited those who were favourable to the success of the "King movement" to conceal its real purport; while others, who have cherished so much affection for the natives or professed so much interest in their welfare, may have been blinded to the inevitable results of encouraging such dangerous aspirations among the half-savage chiefs and tribes ... <i>(Jan 4, 1862,Taranaki Herald,5</i>)

>  <b>REiSCHEK</b> Perhaps, also, he will help to remind them how good, how strenuous life was `in the good old days,' when their Dominion was still half-savage, still unsettled after the toughest of colonial wars, and before the fire and axe of succeeding generations of peaceful settlers had robbed her of so much of her incomparable possession, the native bush. <i>(1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,7,(1933) H.E.L. Priday Preface 7 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1930 Andreas Reischek Yesterdays in Maoriland (1933) H.E.L. Priday Preface 7]

>  <b>MacDONALD</b> The Merino provides good wool returns in its natural quarters - the mountainous back blocks - and ... [furnishes] half-bred ewes as a foundation of the crossbred flocks of Canterbury. <i>(1915,NZ Sheepfarming,37</i>)

Little gave it the name of the estate he managed - Corriedale. <i>(1951,Canterbury Tales,57</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> For the uninitiated, the cross between a merino and a longwool sheep, usually Lincoln, Leicester or Romney, is called a half-bred. . . <i>(1980,Tussock Ranges,219</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> of Maoris, half-caste

>  <b>TUCKETT</b> At each place which i have visited, i have been assured that the Maories are dying rapidly - `perishing like rotten sheep,' these people often say; thus at Kurreroo or Molineux, where there are now half-a-dozen natives, they say that formerly, and at no remote period, about two generations previous to the present, there were above a thousand; and in many other places within the last sixteen years, which is about the extent of the experience of the older beachers, there has been, in many places, a corresponding diminution of numbers. if this is an unexaggerated statement, it is a very distressing one to reflect on. Since Dr. -- visited this settlement, one of the residents, Mr. --, an educated man, has opened a school for half-bred or any other children, and the progress which the children have already made is very encouraging. <i>(May 22, 1844,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1844 May 22 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 223]

>  The crown was called a bull, a cartwheel, a caser, five bob, and most familiar of all a dollar ... The half crown was called a half-dollar, a half-bull, half-caser, two-and-a-kick, and two-and-a-buck. in the latter instance buck stands for sixpence, though apparently this term was rarely used by itself for that coin denomination, but almost always in association with a number of shillings. The representatives of the former genus, however, though common in England, appear to be rare in these seas, while the half-beak, which is of rare occurrence in the British seas, is common all round New Zealand, and is the ordinary gar-fish that is so highly appreciated, especially in Auckland and Dunedin. <i>ibid.</i> 40 HALF-BEAK (see GAR FiSH). <i>(1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,33</i>)

## handy dog
 
 <i>n.</i> a non-specialist working dog; a general-purpose sheep dog that will head, hunt, back, and perform. [(farming)]

>  Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.) <i>(Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Occasionally one sees dogs that will both head and hunt equally well. They are known as handy dogs. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,13</i>)

>  HANDY DOG: A dog which can do both heading and huntaway work. A good one is a champion indeed. <i>(1949,High Country Days,NEWTON,195 ed.</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> So the musterer of to-day, with his pack of five or six dogs, began to take shape. One or two of the border type - `heading dogs' as they're called now and three or four huntaways and `handy' dogs. <i>ibid.</i> 46 . . .Wait, the most wonderful dog i ever saw, a true `handy' dog. He would bring sheep out of any place where dog or sheep could go, and all his master ever said to him was `Here Wait! Here Wait!'; the rest was left to his own judgment and initiative and the sheep would be got. <i>(1951,High Country,5</i>)

>  <b>STRONACH</b> My dogs were undoubtedly the worst in the gang - as a team. i had no heading dog, no decent handy dog, and a rough assortment of huntaways. <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,15</i>) [NOTES: [musterers']]

>  <b>SHARPE</b> A sheepdog is either a huntaway, a heading dog, or a handy dog. <i>(1962,Country Occasions,97</i>)

>  <b>McLiNTOCK</b> Handy Dog: A dog which can do both heading and huntaway work. This `all-round worker' is probably the most useful of all sheep dogs. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/493</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Handy dog: A dog which, endowed with the qualities of both the heading dog and the huntaway, is proficient at both jobs. A good one is a valuable asset and is usually the mainstay of the team. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,187</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> Handy dog: One which can lead and pull sheep if required or stand and bark and hunt as well. Frequently heads when required to hunt and hunts when required to head! all the duties required in sheep yards and woolsheds <i>(1970,Glorious Morning,253</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> Handy dog: A sometimes unpredictable combination of heading dog and huntaway. <i>(1972,Mountain World,310</i>)

>  Handy dog: General-purpose dog that will head, hunt, back, and perform all the duties required in sheep yards and woolsheds. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,24</i>)

## hang by/on its reputation
 
 <i>phr.</i> [ca1949 Kaitaia, of physical objects (R. Mason) ca1949 (Wellington) A man describing a nearly-amputated finger as `hanging by its reputation'. ca1972 July The JBL industrial group, which had gone into receivership, described as `hanging on its reputation for more than a year before the crash'. (The last usage perhaps illustrates the acceptance of the phrase in N.Z. idiom, when its literal meaning can be revived to counterpoint its traditional idiomatic use, in a kind of quasi-pun.  <i>n.</i>

>  <b>TUCKER</b> in our ranks was a very hard-headed gentleman by the name of Jensen who, on arriving at the pub, breasted up to the bar and ordered a `hangman's blood'. The barman confessed total ignorance of just what this drink might comprise. He was told to produce a beer handle, which he did, and was then ordered to go along [17] the entire length of the bar, putting in one nip of whatever spirits were on display. Now at that time spirits were very hard to come by, but Paul Rabone, the proprietor of the Mangatara Hotel, seemed to have an inexhaustible supply. Doing as he was bid the barman proceeded from one end to the other, putting in such things as scotch, gin, bacardi, rum, creme de menthe, and so on. He finally returned to the prospective quaffer of this incredible beverage with the beer mug about quarter-full of a purplish looking liquid. `Now,' said Jensen, `Fill it up with beer.' <i>(1978,Thoroughbreds Are My Life,16</i>)

## hapua
 
 <i>n.</i> a shallow lake

>  <b>SHORTLAND</b> From the spot where Huruhuru left us our path lay along a pebble ridge, with the sea on one side, and the lake Waihao on the other. This `hapua,' as all similar pieces of water are called, has no outlet to the sea except at times of floods, when one is made by the bank of pebbles breaking down at its weakest point: at other times its water oozes through the pebbles and sand. After leaving Waihao, which was nearly three miles long, we passed several small `hapua' similar to it. <i>ibid.</i> 307 HAPUA, a shallow lake, the termination of a river, separated from the sea by a bank of sand or shingles. ## hapuku
 
 <i>n.</i> an important commercial fish =Cod 3b3 2b and grouper 2c. 1844 W Wakefield 1944 W & T Mod Jun Dice ed7 1960 Doogue & Moreland NZ Sea Angler guide 209 1946 JPS 1491966 Turner.] [Maori hapuku[a-micron].] Polyprion oxygeneios; 1. hapuku [`ha:puku] becomes English [ha:`puk],and a mishearing of Maori [p] phoneme gives the commonest pronunciation [ha:`buk] 2. whapuku [` a:puku] [`wa: puku] gives similarly [hwa:`pukd] [wa:`buk] etc. 3. Forms with no initial aspirate may be due to a) de-aspiration in vulgar English b) Maori dialectal de-aspiration (cf. Whangaroa - (North island) Akaroa (South island) initial. in more Maori districts the stress is often on the initial syllable, as in Maori, but in NZ colloquial it is more usually on the second syllable; the Eng. plural can have an -s inflexion; Obsolete (and sometimes mistaken) names include: (New Zealand) cod, cod-fish, rock cod; formerly called New Zealand cod, =groper. [These illustrate anglicisations and corruptions of main Maori dialectal pronunciations: spelling with final a as frequent in English vernacular as that with final u. Williams h&amacr.puku, wh&amacr.puku, kapua. Hapuku is the chief use in the North Island and in Marlborough; in Wellington and the South Island (esp Otago) groper is the chief use. 1895. `Oxford English Dictionary' (s.v. Cod): `In New Zealand, a serranoid fish <i>polyprion pronathus</i>, called by the Maoris hapuku.']

## hard bar
 
 <i>n.</i> [goldmining]

>  The country rock separating two veins approximately parallel with each other has, in certain instances, been found to grade laterally from the vein-wall, where it assumes a highly propylitic facies, to a median rib of dark and only slightly altered rock. These ribs or dyke-like masses are the `hard bars' of the miners. in some cases, however, these `hard bars' are probably due to dykes. <i>ibid</i> 111 The `hard bars' of mining terminology are in most cases merely remnants of less-altered rock, but occasionally as in the case of the `bar' mentioned in the Golden Pah mine, they owe their existence to intrusives. <i>(1907,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,4(NS):101</i>) [NOTES: (Fraser and Adams, Coromandel)]

>  <b>LAiNG & BLACKWELL</b> <i>N. fusca (The Red Beech</i>)... North island: mountainous districts; South island: abundant. The <i>Red Birch</i>. A somewhat similar species is <i>N. truncata</i>, the Clinker Beech, often called the Hard-Beech. <i>(1940,Plants of NZ,139</i>)

>  <i>(Aug 1957,NZ Timber Journal,59/1</i>)

>  Beech ... Hard .. tawhairaunui <i>Nothofagus truncata</i> <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/710</i>)

>  <b>MOORE & iRWiN</b> <i>NOTHOFAGUS TRUNCATA</i>. Hard beech, the only <i>Nothofagus </i>native to north Auckland, is absent from the east and south of the South island. <i>(1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,80</i>)

>  <b>DENNiS</b> ... red beech (<i>Nothofagus fusca</i>) and hard beech (<i>N. truncata</i>) are regular components of the forests on the crest of the scarp above. <i>(1981,Paparoas Guide,157</i>)

>  Above 900 m hard beech is replaced by red beech which begins to dominate the canopy up to the summits of the ikawhenua Range. Also at these altitudes are Hall's totara and tawari. <i>(1983,Land of the Mist,60</i>)

>  <b>DAWSON</b> Five species of <i>Nothofagus</i> were formerly recognised in New Zealand, but more recently two of these have been combined as varieties of one species. ... <i>Nothofagus truncata</i>: hard beech (the wood has a high silica content making it hard). <i>(1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,121</i>)

>  <i>Nothofagus truncata</i> (Hard Beech). <i>(1933,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,14/233</i>)



## hard case
 
 <i>n.</i> a witty person (NZ-US Dictionary); a good-natured reprobate or hoon; Likeable, amusing, conventional, often adventurous, but tough-minded morally tough person; a character; a good sport; a dag; also hard doer, hard lot, hard nail, hard shot, hard thing. [Mary Caldwell of Australia suggests that in NZ the meaning is that one's hard to understand; not the generally accepted NZ meaning but perhaps a regional or special situation meaning, e.g. psychiatric nurses might use this meaning 1984 16 F E30 Pakuranga Coll. 1 HARD CASE -->1984 16 F E38 Pakuranga Coll. 34 HARD-CASE]

>  <b>CRUMP</b> One of the most remarkable attributes of the Hard-case Bastard is his memory for jokes, and when he's not actually engaged in some other kind of hard-casery he keeps up an almost continuous running patter of jokes from his seemingly inexhaustible fund of them. <i>(1971,Bastards i Have Met,59</i>)

>  <b>WRiGHT</b> i thought of old tramps in the summer to stations far out at the back,/ When i met with the hardest of cases that live on the wallaby track -/Men like him, full of tricks and devices, .... <i>(1897,Station Ballads,24</i>) [NOTES: `The Hard Case']

>  <b>McKEE</b> The Hard Case [title] He was as big and as rough as they make 'em .... <i>(1900,Wisps of Tussock,50</i>)

>  <b>KOEBEL</b> The termed `hard case', purly colonial is one, is one of the most widely inclusive and general serviceable appellations imaginable. it may be employed in so many senses, from that of contemptuous pity, of ordinary condemnation, even to that unwillingly extorted admiration. <i>(1911,in Maoriland Bush,282</i>)

>  Shrewd or humorous person <i>(1916,Sentimental Bloke, The</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection) [Aust]]

>  Bill's only enemy was Bill himself. A hard case - yes! As hard as anything in the Army. <i>(1917,New Zealand At the Front,171</i>)

>  They had in their ranks a fair number of dare-devil `hard cases' <i>(1918,New Zealand At the Front,15</i>)

>  <b>DOBSON</b> `Nonsense, he is nothing of the kind, he is a real hard case, a first-class card sharper, and can do exactly what he likes with the cards. <i>(1930,Reminiscences,161</i>)

>  <b>MARKS</b> i don't suppose that in any business factory ... there are more `hard cases' than are to be found in a printing office. <i>(1934,Memories of the Past,68</i>)

>  <b>PARTRiDGE</b> [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... a hard thing, a man noted for his outspokenness, his hardihood, or his kindly if abrupt eccentricity, with which compare the more widely known hard case; <i>(1935,Slang Today,286</i>) [NOTES: 1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today 286]

>  <b>TREADWELL</b> On another occasion ... there was a very `hard case' in the quarter-guard awaiting trial. <i>(1936,Recollections of an Amateur Soldier,203</i>)

>  <b>MARSH</b> He's a hard case, that one ... i reckon he's a real shrewdy. <i>(1937,Vintage Murder,123</i>)

>  <b>PARTRiDGE</b> Hard case. 2. in Australian and New Zealand, a person morally tough but not necessarily incorrigible; also a witty or amusing dare-devil,- one who loves fun and adventure; a girl ready for sexual escapades: all coll. from ca. 1880 <i>(1937,Dictionary of Slang,374</i>)

>  <b>HYDE</b> When they got back, John was encouraging Sandra to roll down the grass bank ... Over and over flashed Sandra's fat legs ... A lean man at John's elbow said, `That's a proper little hard case you've got, Hannay,' and John laughed his best-pleased laugh. <i>(1938,Godwits Fly, The,24,1970 ed.</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> One hard case, called Yorkey, ... is credited with eating two swan's eggs for breakfast- a good effort, even for a hungry man. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,101,1954 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HiSLOP</b> [?a character] This set him thinking, and i must say it took something of the kind to do so, for he was one of the hardest old cases i have ever had the pleasure of collecting a good cheque from, .. <i>(1943,Pure Gold,86</i>)

>  <b>GASKELL</b> Cliff was a hard case. He knew lots of yarns too. <i>(1985,Some Other Country,78</i>) [NOTES: 1950 Gaskell `All Part of the Game' in 1984 Some Other Country 78 [a character] Also 1950 LF 13-18]

>  ~ n. an amusing witty person. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.),617</i>)

>  hard case n.in Australia, tough or roughly amusing character; female of doubtful morals; in N.Z., mischievious person, hard liver. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),10</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Tank Tarrant had been one of the hardest cases that ever passed through Ruamahanga College. <i>(1968,Pagan Game, The,160</i>)

>  <b>DAViN</b> Geoff Dawson, the winger and a well-known hard case, was a bit tight. <i>(1970,Not Here, Not Now,28</i>)

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> A real shithot bloke. Jesus, can he sink the piss. Real hard case that joker. Yah should seen him knocking back those half Gs. Pissed as a fart. ... spewed his ring out. <i>(1971,Bullshit and Jellybeans,85</i>)

>  hard case: used to describe someone who is regarded as a bit of a devil or rough; e.g., `Old Albert's a real hard case.' <i>(1981,NZ Police National Headquarters</i>) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

>  <b>HUNT</b> We were hard cases, too right; we weren't criminals but we had to live like criminals to survive. <i>(1981,Speaking a Silence,18</i>)

>  <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary</i>) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 510, HARD, sense 24; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 225]]

>  ... the inconceivable dislike manifested for Australians by Maori landers (the hard cases for whom the innocent had to suffer) ... . <i>(Sep 15, 1906,NZ Truth,65-5-6</i>)

>  <b>KOEBEL</b> i, the dissolute, the `hard case', as they termed me in their vernacular. <i>(1908,Anchorage,76</i>)

>  <b>ihimaera</b> They were simply remembering Turei as he had been. The hardcase, always ready with a joke, the lovely boy who had once lived among them. <i>(2000,Uncle's Story, The,236</i>)

>  They are a pair of hard cases. <i>(Feb 12, 1924,Otago Witness,71</i>)

>  My little brother is a very hard case. <i>(Jun 17, 1924,Otago Witness,71</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a sexually adventurous or willing woman

>  it appeared from the record that Lydia [a prostitute] was a hard case, and had been to gaol before. <i>(Sep 9, 1905,NZ Truth,12-6-1</i>)

## hard country
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) steep, hilly land with a difficult contour and poor pasture sole.

>  They [Rakahuri Corriedales] are bred on hard country. <i>(Feb 1, 1930,NZ Farmer,211</i>)

>  <b>ALLEN</b> Most of us have a something we simply must do before life leaves us. For him, it was farming which we did the hard way on hard country. <i>(1980,Farm on the Wanganui River, A,7</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> [goldmining]

>  The decomposed andesitic lavas generally possess a characteristic yellowish-brown or grey colour, and form the "kindly country" of the local miners; while the solid andesites and tuffs possess a greenish or dark-blue or purple colour and are generally known as "hard country." <i>(1898,AJHR,C-9/38</i>)

>  After indefatiguable work for about 15 or 16 months, sinking a shaft through hard country, the shareholders came on to a very fine leader at a depth of 150 feet, and on following it up for a short distance the water broke in on them and drove them out. <i>(Mar 24, 1870,NZ Herald,4</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [(farmers' and musterers')]

>  <b>HARPER</b> Some of the men [are], in mining phraseology, `Hatters', that is men who live and work by themselves content with the solitude of well kept huts, a few books [etc] ... .<i>ibid.</i> [144] hard work, their dog as companion, perhaps some poultry, and a weekly visit on Saturdays to the townships to sell their gold and see friends. Whence the term `hatter' i have never discovered; maybe because such solitaries are regarded as `mad as a hatter.' <i>(Jul 10, 1868,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,143,1914 ed.</i>)

>  <b>VON HAAST</b> By one of these [West Coast] `beachers,' a countryman of mine, we were most hospitably entertained, the table being covered with several luxuries of the season which i did not expect in the abode of a `hatter' who are generally of a morose character, and do not indulge in any comforts of life. <i>(1948,Julius Von Haast,529</i>) [NOTES: 1868 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 529]

>  <b>PYKE</b> He was what is termed in mining phraseology, a `hatter', - meaning one who works by himself. ... Alone and unaided he scooped the wash-dirt into his cradle, which he vigorously rocked with his left hand, whilst with the right he ladled water from the river into the `hopper' or seive [sic]. ... He cast aside the `dipper', and hastened towards the eddy. <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,3/vii/95,(1889,1974) ed.</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> Hatter: Whatever the origin of the phrase, `as mad as a hatter' can have been, i have often unsuccessfully endeavoured to discover. But doubtless it is from this phrase that the name of hatter has come to be applied in mining parlance, to one who works alone or without a mate. There are always a few of these unsocial miners about every digging, and their solitariness arises from every imaginable cause. Frequently they are misanthropes, sometimes placid contented creatures, who, so long as they can make a living by `fossicking' about, are happy. / [139]. My host was a hatter and he always kept a spare stretcher for any chance passer-by. <i>(1874,Colonial Experiences,138</i>)

>  <b>HAAST</b> By one of these `beachers,' a countryman of mine, we were most hospitably entertained, the table being covered with several luxuries of the season which i did not expect in the abode of a `hatter,' [[fn] in gold-mining communities those men who work for themselves are usually called hatters, amongst them many originals are found.] who are generally of a morose character, and do not indulge in any comforts of life. <i>(1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,159</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> `i wonder what can be the origin of [the term, hatter]?' `i don't know, i'm sure. Oh, i'll tell you. >  <b>MAY</b> HATTER: a solitary, a digger who works alone. The derivation of this New Zealand expression is obscure. Whence the term `hatter' i have never discovered; maybe because such solitaries are regarded as `mad as a hatter'.  <i>phr.</i> [Jim Cameron writes: In phrase <i>to have the numbers</i>. Probably Australian in origin (Macquarie 1981). Used in NZ eg Bolger <i>A View from the Top</i>. It is not in NSOD or Collins and the definitions there do not fit this usage.]



## have the wood on
 
 <i>phr.</i> to have the/an advantage over, to have the upper hand of: possibly f. tree-falling or axemen's contests, where one wins because one is a chip or thickness of wood ahead of an opponent who loses because he still has a piece of wood to sever before his trunk or block falls: but cf. ADD, and <i>have the googs on</i> [1951 14 M 10 Wellington H.S. 9 WOOD,GOT THE WOOD ON]

>  <b>FULLARTON</b> Then we've taken another hiding. And [check punct.] i thought we had the wood on Jerry today. <i>(1944,Troop Target,168</i>)

>  <b>PARTRiDGE</b> <i>Wood on, have the. </i>`To have an advantage over someone' B., 1941): New Zealand: since ca. 1920. Either rhyming <i>have the goods on </i>or ex the game of bowls. <i>(1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1225</i>)

>  <b>SARGESON</b> wood: <i>had got the wood on</i>, had the advantage over. <i>(1964,Collected Stories,304</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> Some expressions that have been claimed for New Zealand are <i>at the rate of knots</i> `very fast', <i>hook your mutton</i> `clear out', <i>have the wood on </i>`have an advantage over' and the oaths <i>ey Charlie and (By) Christchurch </i>(obviously a neat save suggested by the place name). <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,177</i>)

>  <b>MORRiESON</b> Got the wood on Jamieson. He's coming across with the section. <i>(1976,Pallet on the Floor,118</i>)

>  <i> wood ... have the wood on NZ & Austral. sl. </i>have an advantage over. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,887</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 550]]

>  <b>McGiLL</b> <i>wood</i> have the advantage, often to <i>have the wood on</i>; as in woodchopping contests, at least from 1941; eg `Long as his first serve is not working, you've got the wood on him.' NZA. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,124</i>)

## head-ditch
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a central or feeder ditch in a furrow irrigation system.

>  in the furrow method of irrigation small furrows or corrugations are made in the direction of the slope and connected with a head-ditch supplying water .. Water is taken from the head-ditch, which follows approximately the contour of the surface, into the distributing-furrows, which may be parallel with the ditch or diverge from it. in turning the water from the head-ditch into the furrows the common practice in Central Otago is to make openings in the lower bank with a shovel. <i>(Aug 20, 1924,NZ Journal of Agriculture,108</i>)

>  One of the most frequent and heaviest operations in the preparation of land for irrigation is the formation of head-ditches. <i>(Aug 20, 1924,NZ Journal of Agriculture,115</i>)

## headframe

## heading
 
 <i>n.</i> [(farmers')]

>  ~ (1) People do not as a rule say (e.g.) `fifty cattle' but `fifty h. of cattle'. Up country people usually confine this idiom to cattle and sometimes horses. But i see to-day in `The Press' (June 27, 1933) the editor speaks of a decrease of so many h. of sheep disclosed by this year's sheep return. (C.) (2) A dog goes round to the far side of a mob of sheep and stops them. This is called heading. Hence heading dog, one whose work this is. if he does it neatly he makes a good h See also sheep dog. 3. The owner would say, `i can head with him'.(C; [1874 Kennaway Crusts],p. 45) <i>(Oct 28, 1933,Press, The,17</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]



 
 <i>n.</i> (sheepdog trials)

>  <b>McLiNTOCK</b> Heading. in the long head the competitor stands with his dog in a ring (1 chain in diameter) facing a hillside near the top of which three sheep are set loose. When time is called the dog is dispatched, either on a left-hand or a right-hand cast, up the hill for some 800 yards to a point behind the sheep. On command the dog `lifts' the sheep and, keeping them together, `pulls' them in a direct line back to his master in the ring. To allow the dog to show complete control over the sheep, the run ends with a `hold in the ring'. This involves stopping the sheep in the ring and holding them there. The first stages of the short head are much the same, but over half the distance, 400 yards. At the point where the sheep reach the shepherd, man and dog must drive them ahead down a `drive' which is 60 yards long and 1 chain wide and defined by short poles, to a set of hurdles which are 9 ft apart and parallel with the line of the drive. The sheep are driven between the hurdles and then down a second drive, similar to the first, to the pen or yard, which is 6 ft square. After opening one side, the competitor must stand by the pen gate until the sheep are yarded. The dog must do virtually all the work and his master's right of movement and intervention are strictly limited. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/493</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [(coalminers')]

>  Bords, or headings, are tunnels driven in the coal. ... lead off on both sides from the heading or main drive. <i>(1901,NZ illustrated Magazine,iV/612</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> unpayable dirt removed from a hole and piled near the head of a claim. [goldmining]

>  They are now working the old ground, composed principally of headings and tailings, and even this yields from GBP2 10s to GBP3 per week[.] <i>(Apr 11, 1870,West Coast Times,2</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> The white heaps of `headings' marked the existence of holes clearly enough on the spurs, but in the bottoms of gullies, where ... the heaps of `headings' [129] were very much smaller, [would require a sharp look out]. <i>(1881,Waitaruna,128</i>)

>  The former holders had worked the headings only, leaving the real wash-dirt beneath them, but separated by a layer of barren drift from the upper auriferous strata. <i>(Oct 31, 1865,West Coast Times,2</i>)

 <i>n.</i> [(whalers') Cf gunsman]

## heads and tails
 
 <i>phr.</i> sleep heads and tails, to sleep, one person's feet at the other's head, to double up in a bed in this manner (when beds are few); cf tail in, top and tail. [ca1963 R.M. quoting N.T Moor to sleep head and foot, also used as vt to head and foot (eg children in a bed = to top and tail.]

## health camp
 
 <i>n.</i> (Politics) a camp for the improvement of children's physical or emotional health; a (usu. summer) camp orig. for undernourished or physically deprived, extended later also to emotionally troubled children [see also Davin Gloss]. [Health camps in the US were for tuberculosis; camps for children were set up in Britain but run in entirely different from those in New Zealand. The first to be held in NZ catered for 55 children at Turakina where children sleep in tents, eat meals out of doors, practised daylight saving, and which was run on military lines, the children acting as corporals, sergenats, buglers, etc. New Zealand health camps focussed on prevention rather than cure.]

>  Take, for instance, the cases [sc. of undernourishment] which have come to light at the Campbell's Bay Health Camp. <i>(Jul 2, 1947,NZ Observer,3</i>)

>  This photograph shows sun bathing in progress at Dr. Gunn's Health Camp, Turakina. <i>(Nov 27, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,1</i>)

>  With a background like this, Banks was a candidate for the health camps. Set up after World War One, they were originally intended for malnourished and tubercular children. After World War Two they specialised in children who were nervous, solitary and emotionally troubled... We would never admit to the other kids that we were going to a health camp, because, supposedly, any kid who went to health camps was diseased. <i>(1997,John Banks : A Biography,22</i>)

>  <i>(May 1, 1925,NZ Education Gazette,68/1</i>) [NOTES: [get quot]??]

>  Got a little consolation from Matiu te Huia, who declares that the supposed taua (or war party) is really a heke (or migration) of women & children. <i>(Aug 1, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/117</i>) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

>  Rauparaha ... made preparations for his great heke or exodus from Kawhia to this district. <i>ibid.</i> it was by these two war-trails that the three hekes or migrations ... came to assist their kinsman Te Rauparaha in holding Kapiti ... <i>(1906,TrNZi,38/3</i>)

>  <b>McNAB</b> Accordingly [Te Rauparaha] and the whole of his people set forth on that heke or migration ... <i>(1913,Old Whaling Days,39</i>)

>  <b>GUTHRiE-SMiTH</b> esp. of the great migration Descent is claimed by the Ngati-kahungunu from Rongo-kako, whose son Tamatea arived in ... one of the most famous canoes of the great heke or migration from the mythical Hawaiki. <i>(1921,Tutira,54</i>)

>  Moriori traditions do not go very far back of the heke people ... <i>(Mar 22, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/73</i>) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

>  <b>BUCK</b> The great migration (heke) from Hawaiki is the most famous event in Maori history, because all the tribes trace their aristocratic lineages back to the chiefs of the voyaging canoes. <i>(1949,Coming of the Maori, The,36</i>)

>  <b>JENKiNS</b> They [several Maoris] were going on an up-country heke or migration and in doing so had to cross a combined rail and road bridge over the river. <i>(1970,NZ Mysteries,102</i>)

>  <b>MiKAERE</b> in the winter of 1877, with more than a hundred followers, the prophet set out for Omarama. The people of the heke (migration) called themselves israelites, ... Te Maiharoa's migration followed the coastal trail south to the Waitaki River. ... The heke moved at Te Maiharoa's pace and direction ... <i>(1988,Te Maiharoa,69</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> rafter [ORIGIN: Maori, cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 49.]

>  The heke [rafters] will be structural and go to the ground. <i>(Aug 10, 2005,NZ Herald,B6</i>)

## Helengrad
 
 <i>n.</i> Wellington [After Helen Clark - reference to her supposed overall control of Government]

>  Labour Maori have to go home to their hapu each weekend... Then they return to Helengrad each week, knowing their duty as Labour members is to support the Prime Minister's majoritarian strategies. <i>(Sep 16, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19</i>)

>  "This certainly isn't Helengrad, " one [party insider] said, referring to the prime minister's omnipotence." <i>(Mar 10, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C6</i>)

>  When announcing the weather on his <i>Politically incorrect</i> show, [Perigo] says" "Auckland fine, Hawke's Bay showers, and rain for Helengrad, formerly known as Wellington." <i>(May 9, 2000,Dominion,10</i>)

>  Welcome to the New Zealand of Helengrad and "flag-bearing" art. <i>(Jan 13, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),59</i>)

>  Does she know the Capital's earned the nickname, Helengrad, such is her total command of issues, initiatives and air time? <i>(Apr 27, 2000,Evening Post,6</i>)

>  Mrs Shipley replied that thanks to the autocratic style of Ms Clark, Wellington was now known as Helengrad... <i>ibid.</i> "Double standard abound on the Government's side of the House. Wellington city has already been named Helengrad, and it is for very good reason," Mrs Shipley said. <i>(May 4, 2000,Dominion,2</i>)

>  The full might of Helengrad was marshalled - against the public's right to know about the likely fate of millions of taxpayer dollars, and millions more of poor people's savings. <i>(Mar 3, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16</i>)

>  it has been dubbed 'Helengrad' and only half-jokingly. This Prime Minister runs things her way, with her people... But just when Beltway Wellington was beginning to despair of finding any remaining pockets of good, old-fashioned abusable power and influence, some wit coined the term "Helengrad"... <i>ibid.</i> 21 No old hand in Wellington will argue that "Helengrad" is just a catchy insult. <i>(Apr 14, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20</i>)

>  Take the recent rumble in Helengrad over the PM's husband. <i>(Apr 7, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),65</i>)

>  Ceremonial flypasts in Helengrad just won't be the same with Cessnas. <i>(Apr 21, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14</i>)

>  The last few weeks have been tough weeks in Helengrad," shadow leader of the House Roger Sowry told delegates. <i>(Aug 19, 2000,Dominion,2</i>)

>  A fierce bogywoman stalks the dreams of National MPs. She dwells in Helengrad, communicates with a handful of devoted acolytes (the press) via cellphone, and savages any who dare to question her. <i>(Aug 21, 2000,Dominion,2</i>)

>  Clark is more controlling. When they call it Helengrad, that's what it is. No one comes on the show without Helen Clark's approval, unless they've a mind to cock a snook at her. <i>(Oct 7, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18</i>)

>  The messy boys playing with rocks in the national sandbox found some unexpected friends this week - the formerly stand-offish senior boys from Helengrad High school. <i>(Nov 4, 2000,Dominion,14</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> the Labour Government of Helen Clark

>  But don't think Scroogism is solely the domain of the right. He'd enjoy Helengrad, too. <i>(Nov 7, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C10</i>)

>  Your July 1 edition shows just how little connection the socialist government of Helengrad has with ordinary workers. <i>(Jul 14, 2003,Dominion Post,B4</i>)

>  By 1999, the civil unrest and humanitarian crisis reached a peak, and Helengrad invaded. <i>(Oct 27, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5</i>)

>  One of [National's] most successful barbs is the creation of "Helengrad" - where to step out of line is to be punished. <i>(Jul 15, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C2</i>)

>  This scheme is a natural one for the new state of Helengrad. <i>(Jan 18, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C8</i>)

## herd-testing
 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  A striking case of the value of testing the individual members of a herd is reported from a district where a herd testing association has been established. <i>(Jul 15, 1911,NZ Journal of Agriculture,1/26</i>) [NOTES: 1911 July 15 NZJAg 1/26 in 1966 Turner 45]

>  The herd-testing movement is worthy of special mention. Practically 20 per cent. of the dairy cows in the Dominion are tested for butter-fat production monthly during the milking season. <i>ibid.</i> 346 Although herd testing and milk recording societies existed in Germany, Denmark, England and other countries many years earlier, systematic herd testing appears to have been first developed in New Zealand about the year 1920, when a model Herd Testing Association was established by the New Zealand Department of Agriculture in the Wairarapa. <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,26</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the testing of dairy herds for disease, or to estimate milk production, etc. [cf. cow-testing]

>  We have been rather keen on herd-testing in this district and most folks [get] the herd-tester to do their cows. <i>(Jan 22, 1927,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,35</i>)

>  <b>POWDRELL</b> Herd-testing. - it is strongly maintained that herd-testing - the periodical recording of the weight of each cow's produce together with a butter-fat test from which data the production of the cow for the period is calculated - is the surest way of distinguishing the drones ... <i>(1920,Dairy Farming in NZ,46</i>)

>  As the result of herd testing, greater attention to culling and breeding and improved farm management, the average butterfat yield per cow increased from 154.25 lbs. per annum in 1920-21 to 218.80 lbs. per annum in 1929-30. <i>ibid.</i> 345 The major function of Herd Testing is primarily to determine the milk and butterfat producing ability of individual cows, and from this information to secure accurate data for the elimination of low-producing cows and also to provide a more scientific basis for the breeding of dairy stock. <i>(1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,28</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> A cow with `a good test', that is, milk rich in butterfat, may be more valuable than another cow that gives more milk. About 1910 the practice rose of smpling milk from all the cows in a herd individually and testing the milk for its fat content. This process is called herd-testing. ... it is still not decided whether the word is hyphenated or not. i find it without a hyphen in a publication of the Department of Agriculture in 1950, with a hyphen in a textbook of dairying in 1955. Pronunciation is with one stress, on herd. <i>ibid.</i> 149 in New Zealand, everyone uses the term herd-testing, not milk-testing, because everyone thinks of the dairy industry from a producer's, not a consumer's, point of view. <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,45</i>)

>  Herd testing helps farmers to maintain the standard of their herds - it shows up the lower producers so that they can be culled from the herd. <i>(1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,92</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the testing of dairy herds to assess quality and quantity of milk in each cow.

>  The herd-testing association means more money and better homes for dairymen. <i>(Dec 11, 1920,Hawera Star,10</i>)

>  it is satisfactory to know that farmers are taking a great interest in herd-testing as a means for increasing the yield of butterfat. <i>(Oct 1, 1926,NZ Farmer,1335</i>)

>  Herd-testing in New Zealand since the close of the Great War has been increasingly very rapidly year by year, and it would seem that a stage has now been reached when a steadying-up in the progress of the movement is likely to be evidenced. <i>(Oct 20, 1926,NZ Journal of Agriculture,217</i>)

>  Dairy insight will want at least $10, AB, herd-testing, shed power, shed expenses and animal health will take out the best part of $100 [per cow] ... [herdtesting] <i>(May 2, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,18</i>)

>  A striking case of the value of testing the individual members of a herd is reported from a district where a herd-testing association has been formed. <i>(Jul 1911,NZ Journal of Agriculture,26</i>)

>  High Court ... 3. (in New Zealand) formerly called: Supreme Court. a court of law that is superior to a District Court. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,528</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 353; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 231]]

>  indeed, they risk losing everything if they persist in ignoring "Pakehatanga", i.e. the High Court. <i>(Apr 22, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),25</i>)



## high lands
 
 <i>n.</i> =high country? (mountain-farmer used shortly after) [also highland adjective (1885 cit.)]

>  <i>Nestor notabilis</i>, Gould. Mountain or Green parrot, Sheep-killer, Kea, Kia, Keha, Keo, Kaieo. - By all these names is this troublesome bird known by the highland shepherds and sheep musterers in alpine districts from Lakes Wanaka and Hawea to the river Rangitata. <i>(Jul 1885,NZ Journal of Science,52</i>) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

>  (Dunstan Diggings) The diggings [at Dunstan] extend 80 miles one way and fifteen another. if you want to boil a pot you have to hunt about for dead `Wild irishmen' a nasty prickly little shrub. The high lands abounded with `Spaniards' i suppose from their cut-throat propensities. A kind of very thick grass, grows in a little lump. <i>(Jan 7, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker)</i>)

## high top
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) [mustering and high-country farming] the uppermost grazing land that is used as summer country.

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> The machines shear too near the skin and when the almost naked sheep go out into the high tops 'off the shears' the first cold storm ... <i>(1951,NZ High Country,26</i>)

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> They live in the lonely back huts while they muster the high tops. <i>(1966,Over the River,132</i>)

>  <b>SiNCLAiR & TROTTER</b> Five of us went away out on to the high tops ... <i>(1994,From Caithness to Southland,16</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> This block, which is fenced off from the high tops, is the station's hogget country. <i>(1952,High Country Journey,158</i>)

>  Snow has again fallen pretty thick on the high tops, and fears are rife that numbers of the sheep shorn during the previous blazing weather have perished. <i>(Jan 14, 1882,Otago Witness,13</i>)



## high-country
 
 <i>adj.</i> (Rural) pertaining to or characteristic of mountainous steep country, mainly near the Southern Alps and Central and Southern South island.

>  <b>NEWTON</b> The high-country musterer covers a lot of dangerous country ... <i>(1964,Straggle Muster,94</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> .. this family must surely have no peers as high-country sheepmen. <i>(1973,Big Country of the South island,204</i>)

>  <b>KERR</b> High-country people seem to be invisible to town people, their way of life registering zero on the understanding scale. <i>(2000,High Times in the High Country,200</i>)

>  Due to a change in farming practice our vendors having purchased this property as a going concern now offer this high country herd. [high country] <i>(May 9, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,29</i>)

>  <b>SHARPE</b> .. most high-country owners try to establish a 'snow fence' ... <i>(1962,Country Occasions,158</i>)

>  <b>RiCHARDS</b> it took some getting used to these high-country sheep. <i>(1989,Pioneer's Life, A,44</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i>

>  The high-country tussock grassland of Marlborough has been occupied for pastoral purposes for almost 100 years. <i>(Oct 16, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,293</i>)

>  <b>PASCOE</b> The speech of the men is a slow drawl, sometimes flavoured with Scotch burr ... [fn] High country slang on sheep runs has national characteristics such as referring to a man as a `joker', and using the adjective 'crook' to describe bad weather or ill health, eg `i felt crook on the day the crook weather brought the river up'. Regional slang is also of interest, such as use of `dag' (literally wool fouled with sheep's dung) to mean a `hard case' or unusual character, with an implication of approval, even of admiration. `Rooster' is another variant of `joker'. <i>(1952,Land Uplifted High,162,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> The Kaweka, built in 1936, was the first of several high-country huts that have been erected by the now famous Heretaunga Tramping Club. <i>(1960,Back-Country Tales,28</i>)

>  <b>SHARPE</b> The fall muster is one of the big occasions in a high-country year. it is ... one of the few occasions on which New Zealanders use the word `fall' instead of autumn. <i>(1962,Country Occasions,118</i>)

>  The high-country farms are all in the South island. ... The stock on these high-country farms may graze in altitudes as high as about 1500 to 1800 metres, though most of the `runs' utilise areas up to about 900 m only. <i>(1974,NZ Agriculture,57</i>)

>  <b>WHEELER</b> Though the sunny faces may dry up, the dark faces carry considerable feed, the reverse of usual high-country conditions. <i>(1982,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,13</i>)

>  High-country tenure is being reviewed. <i>(Jul 16, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20</i>)

>  Fiona had married a high country farmer. <i>(Nov 26, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58</i>)



## high-country dog
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a mustering or sheepdog suited to high altitude work by being able to stand up to steep, stony conditions.

>  <b>NEWTON</b> He had everything one could wish for in a high country dog. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,89</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> Crawford's younger brother, Sean also a high country man, and a friend, Hugh McKenzie, were also interested in coming in. <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,175</i>)

## high-country run

## Highlander
 
 <i>n.</i> a breed of sheep developed by Andy and Hamish Ramsden in Hawkes Bay

>  The Primeras breeding enterprise begun in the 1980s, joined with Woodville farmers Andy and Hamish Ramsden, who had developed a maternal crossbred sheep of their own, the Highlander. <i>(Feb 5, 2004,Dominion Post,C7</i>)

>  Their sheep, the Highlander, is firmly established as part of the Hawke's Bay-based multimillion-dollar Rissington Breedline sheep and beef breeding business... in 2000, the three families joined together and decided to develop the Ramsden breed, newly named the Highlander, as a maternal breed alongside the Primera, which would be developed further and marketed as a complementary meat sire. <i>(Feb 28, 2003,Dominion Post,C5</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a breed of sheep

>  So far, the lambs have been mainly sourced from Rissington's client list - farmers using the Hawke's Bay Company's Finn-Texel-Romney maternal composite sheep called Highlander.... "Most of the farmers who have Highlanders are so impressed with them they are holding on to as many lambs as they can to build up their flocks." <i>(Jun 10, 2004,Dominion Post,C7</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a New Zealand-bred sheep based on Finn, Texels and Romneys.

>  Breedline has approached Waipuna to help develop the Highlander. This breed, Donald Polson says, will be based on Finn genetics, Texels and Romneys .. The Te Tui flock will become a franchise flock for Breedline with Highlander ram hoggets being available for mating in 2002. <i>(Sep 14, 2000,Wanganui Chronicle,12</i>)

## hihi
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) stitchbird [ORIGIN: Maori] (See [W.48 Hihi (i) 9. <i>Notiomystis cincta</i>](../W#w.48-hihi-(i)-9.-<i>notiomystis-cincta</i>),[stitch-bird. ..](../S#stitch-bird.-..))

>  10. <i>Pognornis cincta</i>, Dubus. Stitch-bird, ihi. - This shy and now rare honey-eater is seldom met with. <i>(Nov 1884,NZ Journal of Science,276</i>) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

>  <i>Pognornis cincta</i>. - Hihi, Matakiore, Stitchbird. North island. <i>(1886,TrNZi,18/112</i>) [NOTES: (Martin)]

The <i>Zosterops</i> was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail. <i>(1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/14</i>)

>  <i>hihi</i>: stitch-bird. <i>(1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,173</i>)

>  264. <i>Notiomystis cincta</i> (Du Bus, 1839) <i>Stitchbird (Hihi)</i> ... now confined to Little Barrier island only. <i>(1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,69</i>)

## historic hut
 
 <i>n.</i> each of three buildings erected on Ross island in Antarctica during the pioneering expeditions (of Scott and Shackleton) of the early 20th century.

>  [Hdg] Maintenance of Historic Huts in Antarctica. Between 1902 and 1911, three prefabricated huts were constructed on Ross island during expeditions led by Robert Falcon Scott and Ernest Shackleton. <i>(1978,NZ Antarctic Record,1(1) : 10</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> any of a large number of older back-country huts built for mustering, tramping, etc.

>  The back country of New Zealand contains a heritage of about 1400 huts that is unequalled anywhere in the world. These huts were built for the following reasons: wild animal control (~750) sheep mustering (~500) recreation (~150) a range of other purposes including prospecting, scientific studies and castaway sustenance. Others began life as schools and homes and later became huts. These huts have heritage value as the only physical remnant of these activities. ... DOC is identifying a representative selection of key historic huts that can be managed long term to conserve this heritage and allow its appreciation. it is intended to have interpretation signs provided for each historic hut. <i>(2009,internet - see Notes</i>) [NOTES: www.doc.govt.nz/conservation/historic/historic-heritage-topics/huts]
