## hog weed
 
 <i>n.</i> wireweed

>  <b>HiLGENDORF</b> WiREWEED (<i>Polygonum aviculare</i>), also called road weed, mat weed, knot grass, [pig weed,] and hog weed, is common in cultivated land all over the country. it is an annual, with stems up to 2ft. in length trailing over the ground. The stems have swollen nodes (`knot grass') and are very tough (`wireweed'). <i>(1926,Weeds of New Zealand,61,1967 ed.</i>)

>  The news from Britain that hogweed or cow parsnip as it is more commonly called, has been added to the list ... The New Zealand Weed and Pest Control society in recent publication `Standard common Names For weeds in New Zealands' records the name cow parsnip without giving the specific name. This plant could be H. sphondlylium a native of the British isle and at one time widely advocated as a suitable stock food because of its thick fleshy tap root. Hogweed in New Zealand is a popular descriptive name for four different weeds. Two of these, namely the twin cress and wart cress, belong to the same genus. The other two are the wild portulaca and wire weed, which are in no way related. The popular names of the latter illustrate how confusing the use of names like fire weed or wandering willie can be as a means of identifying weeds and plants. These common names of plants frequently have only local significance and in cases may even become obsolete. For this reason botanical names are ... <i>(Jul 23, 1970,Dominion,15/1-3</i>)

>  <b>BUiCK</b> The larger of the adzes, 9 1/2 inches long, was made of a hard, fine-grained black stone commonly used for this purpose ... in shape it was what is known as the `hog-back' type, and had been brought to a high degree of finish. <i>(1937,Moa-Hunters of NZ,204</i>)



## Hogburn head
 
 <i>n.</i> [(Otago mining, ?obs.)]

>  A `Hogburn head' is a stream of water passing through an orifice 16' by one inch, and running for the working day of eight hours ... . the Government head ... . is equal to 2.5 times the Hogburn head ... . and flows for 24 hours. <i>(1872,AJHR,G/4/29</i>) [NOTES: Ulrich Report Goldfields Otago]

>  <b>BEATTiE</b> Soon after the diggings got going properly the Hog Burn was made a sludge channel. The old pastoral interests had to give way before the new mining interests. <i>(1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,171</i>) [NOTES: (Otago mining, ?obs.)]

>  <b>COWAN</b> From January 11 to March 11, 1870, the miners of Naseby went on strike, and finally induced the `water squatters' to lower their rates from five pounds a `Hogburn' head to two pounds. [fn] A `Hogburn' head was the stream of water which would run through a box 17 inches wide by 1 inch in depth with 5 inches of pressure. - J.J.T., `Otago Daily Times,' July 25, 1932. <i>(1948,Down the Years in the Maniototo,43</i>)



## hogger
 
 <i>n.</i> a sawmill mincing machine

>  <b>BiRD</b> The floor underneath contained the drive-shafts and belts that drove the mill, together with the hogger that minced up waste wood for feeding to hungry boilers.<i>ibid.</i> 42. When additional sawdust is required sawmill slabs are fed into the 'hogger' which minces them up for use as fuel. <i>(1998,Viaducts against the Sky,32</i>)



## hogget
 
 <i>n.</i> in NZ used widely on and off (esp. for the meat) the farm (cf hog n1.) (note that animal and meat definitions differ); a) a young sheep between weaning (4 months) and first shearing(14-16 months). b) meat from a yearling sheep between 14 and 24 months. [(farming)]

>  <b>ELDRED-GRiGG</b> The hogget and vegetables, served with gravy and mint sauce, were quickly cleared from our plates and the last traces scraped and then licked off. <i>(1995,Mum,31</i>)

>  His visual sense records the black singlets, the stretched cords and arms of the shearing blades, the scramble of the crewcut hogget to get back upright. <i>(1973,islands,6/360</i>)

>  <b>BEATTiE</b> Names. - Some of the words used to define the sheep were different then, and we read of `hogs' or `wedder hogs,' and `hoggets' or `ewe hoggets.' A hog (or hogg) was a yearling wether, a hogget a yearling ewe. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,85</i>) [NOTES: [1858-1869] Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 85]

>  [first use - previously hog - may represent a different journal keeper] Cut and tailed 130 Ewe ... lambs drafted off Hoggits - tally of whole flock ... 1813. <i>(Aug 30, 1860,Puketoi Station Diary</i>)

>  At the Dunedin Exhibition (1859) the second prize was awarded to the three ewe hoggets shown by Mr. Grigg, ... the first prize being awarded to a fully matured English ewe. <i>(Oct 26, 1865,Nelson Examiner</i>) [NOTES: 1865 Oct 26 Nelson Examiner in 1952 Stevens John Grigg 15]

>  Ewe hoggets (5 in pen) [pounds]6-15-0 to [pounds]7-10-0 each. <i>(Dec 14, 1865,Southern Cross (Wgton)</i>) [NOTES: 1865 Dec 14 Southern Cross in 1952 Stevens John Grigg 17]

>  <b>PHiLLiPS</b> [the first use i have noticed in either journal : lamb - wether, ewe, ram frequent] All hands mustering Mount Misery - took hoggets to woolshed <i>(Dec 29, 1868,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,172</i>)

>  Daging and doseing 530 hoggets. <i>(Jun 8, 1894,Chudleigh Diary,386,1950 ed.</i>)

>  Hogget See Ages of sheep. <i>(Oct 28, 1933,Press, The,17</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>AYSON</b> The wethers were out on the Waiwera hills, and the hoggets ran near the homestead. <i>(1937,Pioneering in Otago,41</i>)

>  <b>BEATTiE</b> Some of the words used to define the sheep were different then [1859] and we read of `hogs' or `wedder hogs', and `hoggets' or `ewe hoggets.' A `hog' (or hogg) was a yearling wether, a hogget a yearling ewe. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,85</i>) [NOTES: (quoting Roberts Diary 1859)]

>  <b>newton</b> HOGGET: A sheep at the stage between weening and when it gets its two teeth, i.e., from eight months to eighteen months of age. <i>(1949,High Country Days,195,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>LiNKLATER</b> i have seen their admirable mutton brought upon the table in such miserable shape that the hogget - so they call a sheep of uncertain age - appeared to have been killed by a bomb. <i>(1953,Year of Space, A,207,1954 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> This in turn led to a dearth of suitable winter pasture country for hoggets. <i>(1960,Back-Country Tales,35</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> Hogget: Lamb after weaning until shorn. <i>(1972,Mountain World,310</i>)

>  The products from this type of farm are wool, some store lambs, a few fat wether lambs, some culled hoggets, store cattle, varying numbers of store or fat wethers, and a draft of `cast-for-age' (c.f.a.) ewes. <i>(1974,NZ Agriculture,59</i>)

>  ~ 8 temporary teeth - centre pair of permanent teeth start to erupt about 12 months... Hogget: Young sheep between weaning (4 months old) and 14-16 months of age. The hogget stage usually ends when the animals are shorn (around 14 months old). There are ram hoggets, ewe hoggets and wether hoggets. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,50</i>)

>  <b>RiCHARDS</b> We will be on hoggets all day. They are big and well wooled, but will be good cutting. <i>(1986,Off the Sheep's Back,75</i>)

>  hogget ... NZ lamb from when it is weaned to its first shearing. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,356</i>) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 532 & 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 234]

>  <b>BURTON</b> New Zealanders are alone in distinguishing hogget from lamb or mutton. Lamb is the meat of any animal from six weeks until it grows its first two teeth, from which time it becomes hogget. When a full set of teeth is grown, the meat from the sheep becomes mutton. <i>(1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,104</i>)

>  Each year, he buys in 1000 replacement ewes as hoggets amd two-tooths, going out of his way to source the best genetics. <i>(Nov 13, 2003,Dominion Post,C6</i>)

>  <b>OGONOWSKA-COATES</b> Ages of sheep. Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A sheep is a lamb until weaned. After weaning a lamb is called a hogget until shorn. A male lamb is a ram lamb until castrated, then a wether. A female lamb is a ewe lamb. After shearing, a ewe or ram lamb is usually called a shorn hogget until cutting the first two teeth. it is then called a two-tooth. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a four-tooth, then a six-tooth and then an eight-tooth or full-mouthed sheep. it is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy <i>(1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,94</i>)

>  i got two bob a week pocket money and for that, i had to feed the chooks, collect firewood, dag the hoggets, dynamite the swamp and drench the bulls. <i>(Nov 2001,Cuisine,132</i>) [NOTES: Daryl Crimp]



 
 <i>n.</i> a hogget carcass comes from a sheep between 12 and 24 months of age, i.e. from yearling sheep. -->2. (butchers') Of meat from hogget; but often as a general (or euphemistic) term for mutton (on hotel menus, etc) (R. Mason).

>  <b>SiMON</b> Behind me, Kitty fusses, taking a leg of hogget out of the freezer for tonight's dinner, rinsing the morning tea dishes, adding things to her shopping list, humming. <i>(1979,Harper's Mother,155</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

>  <b>FERNANDEZ</b> `How's this hogget wool going, Bill?' `First class wool, just first class but it's tender - fleece after fleece. it's heartbreaking.' ... He plucked a specimen of the fine wool from the tender bin ... and gave a sharp tug. The wool parted along a line of weakness in its growth. <i>(1973,Tussock Fever,5</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i>

>  The purchase included 421 goats - 105 bucks and the rest does carrying kids and hoggets. <i>(Aug 11, 1986,Dominion,14</i>)



## hogget block
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) hilly land where hoggets are grazed with little management.

>  The hogget block on Tara Hills consists of four faces, two sunny and two dark. <i>(Nov 21, 1963,NZ Farmer,54</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> ... the former, of 4,000 acres, is the hogget block and although i only saw it from a distance it looked to be warm sweet country. <i>(1972,in the Wake of the Axe,35</i>)

>  <b>DREAVER</b> The really big days were when we mustered the Hogget Block for the summer shearing. <i>(1994,Catlins River Wisp Run,57</i>)

>  The hogget block on the property of Messrs Evans is fairly steep. <i>(Jun 7, 1951,NZ Farmer,12</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> ... Grays Hills itself is now the hogget block. <i>(1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,44</i>)



## hogget country
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) hilly land suitable for hoggets or dry stock requiring little management. (See [hogget block](../H#hogget-block))

>  <b>NEWTON</b> This block, which is fenced off from the high tops, is the station's hogget country. <i>(1952,High Country Journey,158</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> Ewe and hogget country is fairly safe all year round, winter wether country is safe for that time of the year and summer wether country is safe only in the warmer months, when there's little chance of heavy snow. <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,46</i>)

>  <b>PLUMMER</b> ... it was in good grass, no scrub and was good hogget country. <i>(1994,From Drover to Director,60</i>)

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> .. to drive them up past the Clarence accommodation house, and up the Aacheron Valley for ten to twelve miles till we joined another valley to the right leading up into the Alma hogget country. <i>(1962,Life's Roundabout, A,30</i>)



## hogget ill-thrift
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  This term `hogget ill thrift' ... refer[s] ... to lambs that waste away and die in the midst of plenty ... The fundamental reason has not yet been uncovered. [OEDS-omit] <i>(Jul 31, 1973,Weekly News,38/3</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a seasonal metabolic or malnutritional disease of hoggets.

>  <b>DU FAUR</b> The disease known as hogget ill-thrift is fairly widespread throughout New Zealand, and occurs mainly over the late autumn and early winter months. <i>(1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,135</i>)

>  <b>HiNDMARSH</b> Lambs went off fat to the works while the talk round about was of hogget ill thrift. [hogget ill thrift] <i>(1997,Come Be a Pioneer,197</i>)

>  <b>EDGAR</b> .. they [calves] are liable to suffer from an ill-thrift condition similar to that in sheep known as Hogget illthrift. <i>(1959,NZ Farmers' Veterinary Guide,14</i>)

>  Hogget ill-thrift is still common. <i>(1970,Department of Agriculture Report,13</i>) [NOTES: Report: Farming in Hawke's Bay]

## hogsback/hogback
 
 <i>n.</i> 1. a long, sharply crested ridge. 2. a similar shape, especially a cloud heralding a northwest storm in the Si mountains. [(chiefly Cant. mountaineers and trampers)]

>  ... dark clouds ... . a bevy of `hog-backs' <i>ibid.</i> 235 ... hog's back <i>(Jun 1933,NZ Alpine Journal,V/20/180</i>)

>  At sunset the silence of the evening was broken by one of the party dashing into the hut with the cry, `hog's back,' the dreaded harbinger of a N.W. storm. <i>(1934,NZ Alpine Journal,V/21/336</i>)

>  <b>GiLKiNSON</b> ... he showed me a hogsback and told me what it meant. [fn] Term applied to a particularly unwelcome cloud only too well-known to climbers, and almost invariably heralding a north-west storm. An unpleasant sight - but a valuable weather sign. <i>(1940,Peaks, Packs & Mountain Tracks,25</i>)

>  <b>HARPER</b> The most infallible warnings of a nor' wester are the very high clouds of a peculiar torpedo shape, with a hard, rounded upperside like a whale's back - `hog backs' is the usual name among alpine men. <i>(1945,Camping and Bushcraft in NZ,39</i>)

>  it is scarcely neccessary to mention the well-known hogsbacks, those torpedo-shaped clouds which form on the east side of the Southern Alps during a nor'wester and presage bad weather in the ranges, so [28] named by the late A.P. Harper. ... <i>ibid.</i> 40 From our camp on the grassy meadows some battled their way up to the snowline, retreating pellmell when they came face to face with a herd of hogsbacks; ... <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,27</i>)

>  <b>TURNER</b> Hogsbacks are torpedo-shaped clouds in the southern [sic] Alps during a nor'wester. <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,161</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a dark cloud with a rounded top that heralds bad weather in S.i. high country areas.

>  <b>GiLKiSON</b> He showed me a hogsback ..Term applied to a particularly unwelcome cloud only too well-known to climbers, and almost invariably heralding a north-west storm. <i>(1940,Peaks, Packs & Mountain Tracks,24</i>)

>  <b>VANCE</b> its distinctive cloud formation, the lenticular alto-cumulus 'hogback,' has become the warning signal to mountaineers as well as musterers, and the 'nor'west arch' is one of the features of Canterbury. <i>(1965,High Endeavour,41</i>)

>  <b>ASPiNALL</b> i have many vivid memories of storms that would start with the wellknown hogsback clouds in the sky ... [hogback] <i>(1993,Farming Under Aspiring,74</i>)

>  <b>ASPiNALL</b> Even a warm sunny day can show signs of a coming storm when 'hogsbacks', which are large dark clouds with rounded tops, appear over the head of a valley. <i>(1976,High Country Sheep Station,54</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> a spur or ridge of a hill so shaped, cf razor back, whale back; a kind of hill-ridge, cf pigroot. [(chiefly station)]

>  <b>1958</b> Wills and i started for `Hog's Back' ridge, a detached group of the Malvern Hills. <i>(Jan 25, 1849,Torlesse Papers,50</i>)

>  <b>WiLLiAMS & REEVES</b> Only think how much more graceful all the landscape will appear. / No more pigroots, whalebacks, hogbacks - these names that shall not last; / ... Negro-heads shall be re-christened. i for one will take no heed, / While to me there yet remaineth Negrohead, the fragrant weed. <i>(1889,Colonial Couplets,3</i>)

>  <b>LANCASTER</b> On the fifth day Walt climbed to a hog-back ... and looked down on the shapeless gullies <i>(1905,Sons o' Men,14</i>)

>  <b>STEWART</b> The right and half the centre company of Canterbury in the hollow were exposed ..., but on the hogsback of high open ground further west, the inner flank [was] ... raked by machine gun fire from Gird. <i>(1921,NZ Division,112</i>)

>  Hogsback. Spur or ridge of that shape. A common local name both here and in English [?England]. (G.P. W.) <i>(Oct 28, 1933,Press, The,17</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

## hoha
 
 <i>adj.</i> fed up, bored; being a nuisance [ORIGIN: Maori, ca1963 Vincent O'Sullivan p.c. Used frequently by Northland Maori children in sense `fed up']

>  if his cousin didn't get so hoha about all the rellies asking for a hair-cut, Hona Kingi would have what he wants by now. <i>(Dec 1996,Mana,No. 11 : 79</i>)

>  Sometimes i get very hoha with my whanaunga and their attitudes towards simple tikanga, te reo or even the Treaty. <i>(Dec 1996,Mana,No. 14 : 26</i>)

>  May i inform those people that the Te Teko community is hoha with two-faced rubbish that has obviously become a cycle? <i>(Sep 20, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,2</i>)

>  & let's just say it was good / to sit & smoke / & talk there / & not be hoha. <i>(Jun 18, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46</i>)

>  [tiresome, nuisancy] - Hey! When you coming to pick up your hoha kids! They're wrecking the place! <i>(1984,Some Other Country,159</i>) [NOTES: 1972 ihimaera `Game of Cards' in 1984 Some Other Country 159]

>  <b>HiLLiARD</b> `Why didn't Tuku come for it?' `How do i know? too hoha i suppose.' <i>(1978,Glory and the Dream, The,190</i>)

>  He looked at me and i think he was starting to feel sorry for me because i was beginning to get a bit hoha with the whole caboosh. <i>(May 8, 2005,Sunday Star Times,A13</i>)

>  "i get so hoha [weary] with all the negativity around." <i>(Mar 21, 2003,Dominion Post,B5</i>)

 <i>n.</i> boredom [noun]

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> fuss [Noun. **(is this a Maori use; or is it gen. Eng. hooha (see Partridge); ?? is KH confusing the two.]

There's the varying shades of black, brown and grey with a wee dash of white on the forehead and a white tip on the tail...'They're just different,' he says. 'Things like positioning of bones and teeth, everything from the traditional farm animal breeding world, you can forget about when it comes to Hokonuis. ## Hokonui Swindle
 
 <i>n.</i> error for Hokitika swindle, a bar-game played with the numbers on bank-notes. ca1974 Wellington: used in De Brett hotel bar

There'll be some inane feat of manliness to perform, such as a lewd tongue-twister, or a physical show of strength, and he who loses has to down his glass in a gulp. in Otago alone, Hodges found 42 varieties of the theme, with names such as `One Fat Hen and a Couple of Ducks' or the `Hokonui Swindle'. <i>(Oct 19, 1983,NZ Times,3</i>)

>  Other well-known [drinking] games are Hokonui Swindle, Bottles, Fluffy Ducks, Bunnies are Hovering, Cardinal Huff, All Blacks, Matches, and The Amazing Grimaldi Brothers. All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor. <i>(Mar 13, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,16</i>)

>  <b>McGiLL</b> Hokonui Swindle more recent name for and/or version of the Hokitika Swindle, a pub game aimed at financing further drinking. Baker identified the Hokitika version as based on a method of counting `whereby the person who calls a certain number in a sequence pays a specified sum into the jackpot'. Glenn Johnston defines the Hokonui version as a drinking game that combines elements of chance with the ability to hold your liquor and follow a few simple rules - though the deviousness of the caller can also influence proceedings. The aims are simple: to liven things up, get a bit of alcohol consumed quickly and sort the stayers from the pikers. <i>(1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,45</i>)

## hole
 
 <i>n.</i> a miner's excavation in the ground [(goldminers')]

>  <b>Walker</b> (Dunstan Diggings) Monday, got in stores at the following rates and pitched tent. Flour 9d. tea 4/6 a good handful ... Pick 15/6 Shovel 10/- Tin dish 6/- Billy 3/6 small swing pot for boiling Mutton 1/- prospected about 2 miles down the bank of the river, opened a hole Tuesday 9th bottomed the hole, found colour, ... <i>(Jan 8, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker)</i>)

>  ... they reached a bend of the Creek, where they found Ring's party at work, sinking into the bed of it, the water having been turned off a short distance above. Your Committee had a quantity of the stuff taken out of this hole, and washed ..., and every panful of it produced a few specks of gold. <i>(Nov 9, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/26/165</i>) [NOTES: (Report of Sub-Committee on Recent Gold Discovery in the Coromandel District)]

>  From every one of the holes sunk we obtained gold in paying quantities, ... <i>(Jun 29, 1861,Otago Witness,5</i>)

>  <b>28</b> About one hole in every three appeared to be occupied ... No hole at the lower end of the gully, the part i first visited, appeared to have cost much labour. <i>(Sep 27, 1861,NZ Goldfields,1976</i>) [NOTES: 1861 Sep 27 Tuapeka in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 28]

>  in that dip gold has been found in the majority of holes sunk, but to a considerable less extent than at Tuapeka. <i>(Oct 4, 1861,NZ Goldfields,41</i>) [NOTES: 1861 Oct 4 Dunedin in NZ Goldfields 1861 (1976) 41]

>  One hole has been bottomed on this range. [check=claim] <i>(1862,Otago: its Goldfields and Resources,26</i>)

>  <b>WEKEY</b> fn `To bottom a hole,' is a peculiar expression used on the mines in Australia; it means to convey the sinking of a shaft down to the bed-rock on which the auriferous drift generally rests. <i>(1862,Otago As it is,64</i>)

>  <i>(Jun 23, 1887,Chudleigh Diary,356,1950 ed.</i>) [NOTES: Got samples [of quartz] from several holes to take away and have assayed.]

>  <b>HOPEFUL</b> [Colonial slang] if a man isn't `up to the mark' he is called `a regular shicer!' This phrase originated from the gold diggings. Supposing a man is digging, but without success, and he therefore abandons his hole, it is called a `shicer' - that is, the ground was called a `shicer' or duffer, thus the origin. <i>(1887,Taken in,135</i>)

>  <b>PFAFF</b> i bought and sold flour ..., got a 3-1/2 oz. nugget from the bottom of a hole that had been left, made a rise of [pounds]300 out of a pocket of gold like horse beans. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,115</i>)

>  <b>MiLLER</b> i was on gold all the time. i had sunk my first prospect hole at the lower end of a shallow depression ... and had struck the deepest part of the lead. it was a narrow gutter, no more than a foot wide at the most, and rich in heavy gold. <i>(1946,There Was Gold,69</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> [in phrase sink a hole]

 <i>n.</i> [(gumdiggers')]

## holey
 
 <i>n.</i> a marble game [cf. holes, holesy]

>  <b>FRAME</b> `Treasure' i played ringie and holie. i played funs and keeps. i had pee-wees and bully taws and changers that weren't made of glass mind you. And i won nearly every game because the kids were so dazzled by the look of my stinkers. ... They came for miles to play marbles with me ... <i>(1951,Lagoon, The,116,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMiTH</b> There is only one record of a New Zealand game in which a formal penalty element entered. This was a game of marbles called Dumps and was played at Wakefield in 1875. in this game the loser, in a marble game of Holey, was required to hold his marble partially exposed between the fingers of his closed fist [for others to shoot at]. <i>(1953,Unorganized Games,2/719</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMiTH</b> in the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (in more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. The last was more usually a girls' game. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,174</i>)

>  <b>KEiTH & MAiN</b> ] [Photo caption] Marbles became `in' or `out' capriciously but someome always knew the rules of the various games - `holey,' `liney' and, seen here, `ringey' - which could be played for `funs' or `keeps.' <i>(1984,NZ Yesterdays,288</i>)

## Homaiacky
 
 <i>n.</i> a former children's game

>  <b>SUTTON-SMiTH</b> Of the Help-He games, Kick the Tin, is the most widely known. A tin is placed in the centre of a circle. One He is in charge of the tin. He can only tag the other players when his tin is in the centre of the circle. Any players he catches must stay in the circle. Any non-caught player can help and free the other caught players by running through the circle and kicking the tin out of it. Other names for this game are: Kick the Boot (Gisborne [18]90), Knock the Block or Homaiacky (Nelson [18]95), Kick the football or Piacky (Mangatainoka). <i>(1953,Unorganized Games,2/513</i>)

>  <b>SUTTON-SMiTH</b> in a few tagging games the players joined hands with the He when they were caught and helped him catch the other players. These games were known as The Bellahonie (E-21) (Wellington, 1910), Kick Post One (Hampden, Otago, 1880), and Ballyhooley (Wellington, 1920). More popular were those games in which the players helped one another to fight the He, and of these the most widespread was the game known as Kick the Tin (e-3), Kick the Boot, Kick the Block, or Homiacky. in this game the He was put on guard of a jam tin placed inside a small circle marked on the ground. [Other players hid: those He could see he named and tapped the tin three times and `captured': other hiders waited till they had chance to kick tin out of circle: then all were free again.] <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,80</i>)

England : Colonial, prob first in U.S. (cf Thornton) in 18c. : 20c Aust and NZ esp. go, at home.] (it is perhaps possible to distinguish among the earliest recorded uses, a specific reference to England, rather than other parts of the British isles, or to the British isles themselves. ## home and hosed
 
 <i>phr.</i> (informal) equivalent of Brit. home and dry [Alistair Paterson, 34B Methuen Rd, Avondale (Fax.(09)8282209 says used in 1940's at the Aurora Sailing Club, Nelson, to describe a boat that's finished a race (usually successfully) and has been hauled from the water onto the hard and hosed down. It's my recollection (DEH) that the same phrase was used then also by racing commentators and it was transferred to the winner of any competitive event. Partridge ("A Dictionary of Catch Phrases") discusses "home and hosed" as an Aus. variant of "home and dried on the pig's back." He also says: "The predominantly UK and Anglo-Irish elab. is 'home and dried with the blanket on,' which 'stems from horse-racing, but . . . is used for any mission accomplished' (Skehan, 1977)."]

>  Homin' Hosed peeled off from behind Bogan Fella in the home straight and got up for victory. <i>(Nov 10, 1999,Dominion,48</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> `Home and hosed,' said Spandau. `Don't be so cocky,' i tell him. <i>(1970,On the Ball,139</i>)

>  We were not home and hosed, but it gave us a little bit of an uplift as it was the seventh day in the raft and we thought we were making progress ... <i>(Jul 14, 1988,Dominion,1</i>)

>  home ... 13. home and dry. Brit. sl. definitely safe or successful. Austral. & N.Z. equivalent: home and hosed. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,535</i>) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 358; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 235]]

## home invasion
 
 <i>n.</i> [Jesse Sheidlower (jester@panix.com) says a quick US search turned up this term in 1989 (<i>Chicago Tribune</i> Nov. 23, p. C26 "Suburb Cops Zero in on Ring Involved in Home Invasions" and believes there would be much earlier examples; his earliest was a 1978 article in a trade magazine about credit cards. Michael Proffitt (mproffitt@oup.co.uk) has this from 1988 Sara Paretsky <i>Toxic Shock</i> (1990) xxix. 214 "The steel-lined door I'd had installed after my last home invasion had held" and says they have Canadian evidence from 1993 and "home invasion" and "home invader" from Australian newspapers from 1994 onwards. Wayne Glowka (Georgia College & State University; wglowka@mail.gcsu.edu) has a Canadian usage from 1997 <i>Globe and Mail</i> 9 Dec. p. A7 "The terms home invasion or reesidential robbery surfaced in Winnipeg about 18 months ago after a series of violent break-ins where seniors, who happened to be at home at the time, were injured." He also quotes a correspondent who says the term has been common in British Columbia for perhaps 10 years.]

>  He was awoken by four people wearing balaclavas before "home invasions" became a catchphrase. <i>(Jan 23, 1999,Dominion,19</i>)

>  Mrs Shipley will announce the Government's response to the "home invasions" when she outlines the Government's legislative programme at Parliament's first sitting... Jenny Shipley announced the Government would draft a new definition of home invasion following a series of high profile incidents in the last three months. Sentences for home invasion crimes.. would be increased by a maximum of five years. <i>(Feb 16, 1999,Dominion,1</i>)

>  i move, <i>That the House take note of the report of the Justice and Law Reform Committee on the Crimes (Home invasion) Amendment Bill</i>... Home invasion is not an everyday offence. <i>(1999,NZ Parliamentary Debates,575 : 17550</i>)

>  The definition of home invasion.. is intended to cover all situations where an offender commits an offence in the process of entering, while inside, and while leaving, places where people live. in the bill as introduced, a home invasion must occur in a "dwellinghouse"... The definition of "dwellinghouse" is.. .intended to encompass the variety of places in which people can live, including caravans, mobile homes and other structures. it focuses on the use to which a building is put, and is therefore not intended to include buildings or parts of buildings that have some other primary purpose, such as a commercial buildings or hospitals... 17A.. 'Dwellinghouse' means (a) a building or other structure, or part of a building or other structure, that is used by the occupant principally as a residence; or (b) A mobile home, caravan, or houseboat, that is used by the occupant principally as a residence; "Home invasion", when used in the expression 'the offence involved home invasion'.. means that the person who committed the offence did so... (a) While breaking and entering, or otherwise unlawfully entering, an occupied dwellinghouse; or (b) While in an occupied dwellinghouse, after having broken and entered, or otherwise unlawfully entered, the dwellinghouse; or (c) While breaking out of an occupied dwellinghouse; or (d) While otherwise unlawfully in an occupied dwellinghouse <i>(1999,NZ Statutes,262</i>) [NOTES: Report from the Justice & Law Committee]

>  The agency is reviewing its policy.. after a 13-year-old responsible for nine previous aggravated robberies led a brutal home invasion attack in a Gisborne couple earlier this year. <i>(Aug 14, 1999,Dominion,25</i>)

More than simply expressing the fundamentals of the crime, "home invasion conveys something of that moment when a gang bursts through the door. <i>(Jan 30, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26</i>)

>  <b>BEATTiE</b> The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. in this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.' <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,11</i>)

>  <b>BEATTiE</b> it is usually understood that in the early days the word `station' denoted the owner's house and its immediate buildings, while `run' meant the whole property. Strange to say, i only noted the word `station' twice, and each time with a diverse meaning. On July 21, 1865, the diary says: `Sold 17 head of cattle - remaining on station 15 head.' Then on September 11, 1865, we read: `Wilkinson returned to the Home Station.' The first of these entries means the whole run - the second the homestead or main buildings. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,115</i>) [NOTES: -->1947 Beattie Early Runholding 115 quoting 1856 July 21 Puketoi Station Diary]

>  <b>BEATTiE</b> The custom in the old days was to call the buildings on a run `the station,' and the land that went with it was `the run.' On a big property you could find several `stations,' and the principal one was called `the home station,' while the others were `out-stations.' This was the old Australian usage which was carried over to New Zealand at first, but gradually the signification was altered by loosely calling the whole run a station, and then the real station became a homestead and the out-stations became shepherds' huts. in this present book it will be noticed that generally the writer has preserved the olden custom of calling the main buildings the station and the land the run. The runs over in Australia being, as a rule, much larger than those in New Zealand, the `station' and `out-station' phraseology was preserved much longer than over here, where even in advertisements in the late 'fifties we see the English word `homestead' ousting the colonial word `station.' <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,11</i>)

## homeward bounder
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>MAY</b> it was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of the `pilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access. <i>ibid.</i> 275 The richest claim was always a `homeward-bounder'. A Nelson digger recalled how at work his mates talked of `trips to Europe, going back for a week, and astonishing the Natives generally'. <i>ibid.</i> 329 J. F. Byrne & Co. showed off their wares by the light of six kerosene chandeliers and advertised, THE REAL HOMEWARD BOUNDER!/An ounce to the Dish can be Saved/ BY BUYiNG YOUR/CLOTHiNG AND BOOTS AT THE CORiNTHiAN HALL/ NEW RUSH NEW RUSH /Peg out your claims at the Corinthian Hall if you want to strike a good lead/Dead on the gutter/ BUY YOUR CLOTHiNG AND BOOTS AN THE CORiNTHiAN HALL/ <i>(1962,West Coast Gold Rushes,244,1967 ed.</i>)

## hoodat
 
 <i>exclam.</i> who say hoodat, a catchphrase popular among students etc. in 1950's and early 60's, said especially as a welcome to a newcomer to a group, or outsider. Often a meaningless saying. (from who dat say who dat?, from the coloured joke about Rastus / Hori / Jacky etc, who comes home suddenly when a friend is in bed with his wife. The adulterer gets out of his bed, and tries to creep out under cover of darkness. Rastus hears him,in the dark, and says `Hoo dat?' being answered by silence, until the adulterer bumps into him in the dark, and says himself `Hoo dat?' Rastus immediately says `Hoo dat who say hoo dat'. The story has many variants, and is variously placed in stage Black, Maori or Aboriginal contexts.

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> a humanitarian, ethical or political objector to military service; a person whose objection to military service is based on other than religious convictions; a political or humanitarian objector 1941-5. ACB: ca1941-45 A.C. Barrington; J. McCreary; a non-religious objector [WWII]

>  <b>GRANT</b> The third group were non-religious objectors (known as 'hoons'in camp) who were a diverse group, often individualists, who opposed war for a variety of ethical and humanitarian reasons... Christian pacifists and some 'hoons' mixed well and learned from each other. 'Hoon' George Gunn recalled that the Methodists "simply glowed with humanity." <i>(2004,Question of Faith, A,53</i>)

>  <b>FOOTE</b> However, a number of Christian pacificsts and some 'hoons', - humanitarian/ethical/political objectors - felt this argument was a cop out. <i>ibid.</i> 62 The majority of the Christian pacifists in detention were Methodists. Hoon George Gunn wrote, "they simply glowed with humanity." <i>(2000,Bread and Water,14</i>) [NOTES: Used in WWii period]

>  <b>CRYER</b> During the war the same word [sc. hoon]underwent a complete reversal of meaning. Poeple who were conscientious objectors on other than religious grounds were known to the military as hoons... <i>(2001,Curious Questions,102</i>)

>  <b>HAM,iLTON</b> i hadn't been in detention long when i heard his name mentioned ...He hadn't gone to jail with the first group ...They reckoned he'd stuck to his religion all through and the Hoons [(fn) non - religious groups] gave me the impression that he took his religion seriously ... you couldn't take much notice of the Hoons of course, not about a thing like that. Most of them just lumped the religoes together ... . <i>ibid.</i> 164 There was a sort of line drawn in the [detention] camps betwen the Hoons and the religoes. ... The religoes were divided again into God knows how many sects and amongst the hoons were absolute pacifists, pacifists, Communists, Anarchists, humanists, and plain dodgers. <i>(1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,154</i>)

>  <b>SANDYS</b> `i'm lucky to be here [in a detention camp for conscientious objectors]. Some are war resisters- ... Then there are the Christians. ... They're still trying to work out how the hell they landed up [here] ... The majority are Hoons - military defaulters. >  <b>BATHGATE</b> [Note] Utu, revenge or satisfaction on the principle of blood for blood; also payment in more modern times. <i>(1889,Far South Fancies,156</i>)

>  <b>H W ORSMAN</b> A. Maori contexts. Orig. a European rendering of the Maori noun utu, return (for anything ); satisfaction, ransom, reward, price, reply' (Williams); not to be used confused with uto `revenge', a confusion evident in many of the explanations of the meaning of utu). The word widely used was in all the above senses by Europeans who had dealings with Maoris, from the general `return for work, injury, etc.' to the concrete `money' it is often found constructed with the definite article `the utu, hutu' etc. translating the original Maori indefinite article, or adjective `some' he utu `an utu, some utu'. (Occas. constr with indef. article, see 1834). in later European usage the definite article was dropped to conform to English idiom eg' `give me the hoot' becomes `give me (some) hoot' The following is perhaps a `transitional' use 1828 C Davis journal Colenso Papers 3/18) `Another chief had been killed as a utu or payment'. (is this [ei utu] reflecting Maori [(h)e utu], as well as English a for an?). The phonology, resulting in the English hoot, parallels that of toot from tutu, with the final unvoiced [u] not being heard by English ears. The initial [h] derives perhaps from a syncopation of [he utu]; but more prob. from the var. or error noted on p. 4 of 1842: Maunsell Grammar of the New Zealand Language (4th ed) 1894: `in pronouncing u, the speaker will have to guard against the error of those who prefix the aspirate when no aspirate is admissable. According to the u, utu, etc., are pronounced as if spelt hu, hutu.'. <i>(1990,Personal Communication</i>)

>  The land that's waste they'll parcel oot, / ... And sell't to all that's got the hoot. [fn] Utu: Maori word for money. <i>(1964,Book of New Zealand, A (J.C. Reid),285</i>) [NOTES: (Otago Gold-miners' Song)]

>  <b>WiLSON</b> `Here's some hoot.' Don handed him a couple of fives. <i>(1973,NZ Jack,110</i>)

>  hoot n. Austral. & N.Z. a slang word for money. [< Maori utu price] <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,538</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 360; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 236]]

>  <b>WiLSON</b> But we soon found out he was hitting the booze too much and spending all his hoot on the ponies. <i>(1984,South Pacific Street,47</i>)

>  For some reason this paper had deployed an investigative team to find out how much hoot the lads had received for their capers on the veldt. <i>(Nov 28, 1986,Contact (Wgtn),2</i>)

>  <b>McGiLL</b> hoot money; corruption of Maori `utu', ransom or price; also hootoo, hout and hutu; c. 1840. <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,58</i>)

>  My brothers' slang and `funny' sayings delighted me. ... i remember [126] such words as `batty', `hoot' and `spondulicks' and many that ... were corruptions of Maori words. i spell them here as they sounded to me then: ehoa, harka, kupai, kure, munga munga typo, markuta, pooku, tangy. <i>(1988,Through the Looking Glass,125</i>) [NOTES: (Meikle)]



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [Hoot, is first recorded as slang from Otago in 1864. This is reasonable. In the more Maori districts the use would still have primary Maori meanings and associations, while in Otago, where there were few Maoris, the transference to purely European idiom be could completed much earlier. This transference was probably helped by rhyme with loot (cf the ? mistaken interpretation of 1845 Barnicoat Journal 163. `Our first endeavour was to get a native as a guide over the hills `How much the loot' of course was the answer to our enquiries.') though op. cit 190 `bargained for utu'); loot could have been an occasional joking word for money, although it is not attested in NZ until fairly recently but cf Partridge. Supp. Loot 3. `Scottish slang for money received on pay-day' Services: ca 1925; anglicised as hoot, money, cash.]

>  Picton opens up a glorious harvest for the Dunedin harlots, whose trade here is, from want of hoot, decidedly on the wane. <i>ibid.</i> 3/12 We shall soon have no `hoot' to pay the piper <i>(1864,Saturday Review,X62</i>)

>  <b>BARR</b> The land that's waste they'll parcel oot, /...../ and sell't to all that's got the hoot. (FN) Hutu, Maori for money. <i>(1879,Old identities, The,333</i>)

>  <b>MORRiS</b> ~ slang term for compensation, payment, money; characteristic corruption of Maori Utu(q.v.). <i>(1898,Austral English,201</i>)

>  `There are several specimens of bush slang transplanted from the Maori language. `Hoot' is a very frequent synonym for money or wage. i have heard a shearer at the Pastoralist Union office in Sydney when he sought to ascertain the scale of remuneration, enquire of the gilt-edged clerk behind the barrier, `What's the hoot, mate?' The Maori equivalent for money is utu, pronounced by the Ngapuhi and other northern tribes with the last syllable clipped, and the word is very largely used by the kauri-gum diggers and station hands in the North island. The original meaning of first settled in New Zealand, they found that the savage inhabitants had no conception of any recompense except the grim recompense of blood. Under Christianizing influences the natives were induced to forego the blood-revenge for injuries, on receiving a solatium in goods or land, and so utu came to have the double meaning of revenge and recompense, and eventually became recognized as the Maori word for money.' <i>(Jan 12, 1896,Truth (Sydney)</i>)

>  ... the most important [Chatham island] edible sea-birds: AS WRiTTEN AS PRONOUNCED ENGLiSH hopo ho[macron]p' albatross hakoakoa ha[macron]ko[macron]k' mutton bird taiko tchai[macron]k' pied shear water tupoupou tchu[macron]poup' pied blue billie <i>(1928,Bishop Museum Memoirs,Vol. iX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 358</i>) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs]



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Within minutes of play starting Hopoate was written indelibly and ever so elegantly into the language, A quite bad shot brought the threat, with the appropriate gesture, of a one-finger hopo. A rank short bowl was a two-finger hopo, an appalling misjudgment of a shot a three-finger hopo...Then the skip... looked stricken, turned ashen-faced and disappeared at unusual speed into the club-house - proof-positive the hopo is here to stay as the ultimate deterrent to poor play in any sport. <i>(Apr 5, 2001,Evening Post,6</i>)

>  At least all this made Trevor Mallard's John Hopoate-like gesture toward world rugby boss Vernon Pugh look comparatively trivial. <i>(May 4, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15</i>)

## hopper
 
 <i>n.</i> Orig. cheese-hopper; applied by bacon-handlers to the maggots which breed in bacon; and more widely to any sort of maggot (from blow-flies in meat): from ca1910 (WHBO).



 
 <i>n.</i> a fish

>  TREVALLY (a) Scientific name: <i>Caranx lutescens</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Trevally; New Zealand Pompano. (c) Other common names: Hoppers (fish in uncleaned state). (d) Principal localities where taken: [Largely confined to northern waters and south to Cook Strait]. <i>(1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,48</i>)

>  [species name] trevally .. [scientific name] <i>Caranx georgianus</i> .. [other name(s)] hoppers, jackfish <i>(Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [Cf dipper.]

>  He was what is termed in mining phraseology, a `hatter', - meaning one who works by himself. ... Alone and unaided he scooped the wash-dirt into his cradle, which he vigorously rocked with his left hand, whilst with the right he ladled water from the river into the `hopper' or seive [sic]. ... He cast aside the `dipper', and hastened towards the eddy. <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,3/vii/95,(1889,1974) ed.</i>)

>  <b>McARA</b> Hoppers: Storage bins for ore both on the surface and underground. The stamp hoppers held sufficient crushed ore for twenty-four hours' operation. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),324</i>) [NOTES: (Glossary of Waihi Mining Terms)]

## Hori
 
 <i>n.</i> a Maori [Maori Hori[o-macron], alteration of George]. it was often used as a stage-Maori name, or as a general term of reference or address to an un-named Maori. Unlike Hongi, it was not at first so objectivable as used by English speakers (but cf the 1933 quotation). it is used by Maoris among themselves humorously or sardonically; cf George, hongi @n. (From Maori rendering of English George, formerly fairly common as a name among Maoris, esp. during reigns of Kings George iii-Vi; cf.) 1a. a particular Maori named Hori [(informal, offensive in non-Maori use) Spg horri, horry; pl often.]

## horopito
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Drimys axillaris</i> a small, slender, evergreen tree with aromatic bark. Also called pepper tree. [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  The kitchen gets marks for initiative in sourcing ingredients, having somehow found somebody to supply piko piko, horopito and other New Zealand bush herbs, some of which, the waitress told me, had gone into the Hubba Hubba spice rub for the salt water prawns and calamari. <i>(Aug 15, 2002,Dominion Post,D3</i>)

>  Horopito (Pseudowintera) was used for skin and venereal diseases and Mother Aubert, in a letter to the French Consul, wrote that a chemist at the University of Paris considered her medicine Karana, which contained horopito, was "superior to Quinquina (quinine). it has been very useful to me in cases of anaemia, of debility, of continuous diarrhoea etc, and in recovery from temperatures." <i>(Aug 24, 2002,Dominion Post,F16</i>)

>  <i>horopito n</i>. NZ pepper-tree. [M] <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,361</i>)

>  <b>THATCHER</b> in London the swells in the park drive all round, But the diggers drive here with a pick underground; And the props that they use, surely everyone knows Ain't the same used in London for hanging up clothes. The women use fans* there, the men use them here, Though to cockneys that statement may sound very queer, And the fellows that frequently hang round hotels, Out here are called loafers, at home are called swells. -->[p 89 fn] * A fan is a machine for pumping air down the shafts. <i>(1875,NZ Songster,No.3/88</i>) [NOTES: London & the Diggings]

>  <b>KENNEDY</b> Drinking here is fostered by the appearance and number of the `hotels'. `Hotel' sounds more respectable than `public-house'. The bars are opener, more numerous and less clandestine-looking than at home. <i>(1877,Colonial Travel,195</i>)

>  <b>CLAYDEN</b> Hotels are quite a feature of colonial life. They are mostly well-fitted up, and altogether unlike the average English public-house. They are in fact public boarding-houses. <i>(1879,England of the Pacific, The,50</i>)

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> [?=shanty] Some of the keepers of the shanties in the interior of the North island, which they dignify with the name of hotels, ...[get] the maoris to run up a long score for liquor and then secure a mortgage over their lands. <i>(1880,Far South Fancies,99</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> ... one [building in the goldfields township] being the `General Store', where every description of merchandise is sold; the other a public house, ... `The Maori Hen Hotel', where alcoholic liquors ... are vended. <i>(1881,White Hood and Blue Cap,5</i>)

>  <b>HOPEFUL</b> The town [Lyttelton] was hilly ..., and for so small a place there seemed no end of `Pubs', or Hotels as they are called here, at each corner of which stood groups of men, idling and gossipping - in fact, the male element prevailed greatly, and it was rather an ordeal for the `New Chum' to have to go through the ranks this way. <i>ibid.</i> 134 if this is agreed they will adjourn to the nearest inn, or hotels as these little match-boxes are called; ... When one friend meets another very often the greeting will [135] be, `Are you going to stand `shout'?' in other words, `Are you going to stand drink or `treat'?' if this is agreed to they will adjourn to the nearest inn, or hotels as these poor little match-boxes are called; and in fact there is a great deal of standing `shout' in the Colonies, both in public and in private. <i>(1887,Taken in,71</i>)

>  <b>BARLOW</b> i entered a small hotel (by the way, every beer-shop in New Zealand is an hotel) ... <i>(1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,3</i>)

>  <b>D'AViGDOR</b> The business is simple and easily learnt. To enter it the first process is to hang about the bar of a popular `hotel' (Anglice:public-house) and grumble loudly at the hard times and low wages, not forgetting to abuse the Government for not finding work for everybody. <i>(1888,Antipodean Notes,154</i>)

>  <b>MiTCHELL</b> One night, at the hotel where i put up, several of us had a go in at Yankee grab. i was unlucky. Next morning ... i had but one pound left. <i>(1889,Rhymes and Rambles,19</i>)

>  <b>BELL</b> About the centre of the township, on the main street, two or three hotels, already mentioned, stood, with most of the other places of business scattered around in their vicinity. The hotels were at such a distance from each other as to allow the landlord of each to stand at his own door and watch with feelings of envy any unusual trend of customers seeking refreshment at the other. They were large, pretentious buildings of their class, with verandah and balcony to each, and were well-conducted inns, the accommodation afforded to travellers being all that could be expected - equal, indeed, to that of some of the best hotels in the larger centres. <i>(1899,in the Shadow of the Bush,21</i>)

>  <b>FiNLAYSON</b> They put the gig in the shade of the trees in the hotel paddock and let the pony go in the horse paddock adjoining. <i>(1948,Tidal Creek,100,1979 ed.</i>)

>  <b>R. MASON</b> The practice of calling hotels `Hotel Astor' instead of `Astor Hotel' etc. dates i think from c. 1928, and was i think inspired by `Chateau Tongariro' which was built about then. i can remember a number changing, including the Astor in Auckland & all were subsequent to the name `Chateau Tongariro' <i>(1955,Personal Communication</i>)

>  <b>GOLDBLATT</b> ... and then the long main street, shop-lined; these make up the New Zealand township. There will be ... at least a couple of `pubs', with hotel attached ... <i>(1957,Democracy at Ease,8</i>)

>  [Two correspondents] wonder why the Dunedin rugby ground, Carisbrook, is called "The House of Pain." Otago rugby historian Dave McLaren says that several people claim to have coined the nickname, but the most likely person is ex-player (and children's book author) Brent Pope. Apparently, some time in the mid to late 80s, Pope was heard to exclaim, after a particularly hard training run inflicted on them by coach Laurie Mains, "Why the hell do we keep coming to this bloody house of pain?" it went public on September 27, 1992, when North Harbour coach Brad Mourant said much the same thing in his after-match function speech. <i>(Feb 12, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48</i>)

>  There was no prouder man in the bowels of the House of Pain later than All Black skipper Anton Oliver... <i>(Apr 6, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B2</i>)

>  "This is our House of Pain. Whoever comes here, we show them the way home." <i>(Aug 21, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31</i>)

>  A group of South African rugby supporters in the pub, polite as hell, still fuming after the All Blacks destroy the Springboks at Carisbrook, one sporting his new "House of Pain" T shirt. <i>(Aug 21, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36</i>)

>  The House of Pain, it was said, would fill the Ocker hearts with ice. <i>(Aug 12, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A2</i>)

>  <b>PALENSKi</b> it is often assumed that the phrase [sc. the "House of Pain"] came to be applied by visiting teams because of the perceived difficulty of winning at Carisbrook. it actually began, however, in the late 1980s within the Otago team when players referred to Carisbrook as the House of Pain, because of exhausting training sessions. it was once attributed to an Otago player of the time, Brent Pope, and he happily claimed the credit for it, but it's difficult to pin down to one person. it's only in recent years that it's been seen as the House of Pain for visiting teams - a belief encouraged by Radio Sport (which began in 1998) commentators who had little or no acquaintance with either the ground or the phrase. <i>(Sep 28, 2004,Letter</i>)

## how's that?

[ha'uz set] with intonation pattern [B ]. Perhaps assoc. with the cricketer's' coy Howzat?.. Phs dial in origin: cp EDD How adv. ii 1. 22 Howat, How that how was it that why was it? Cum. [through the quot. suggests a different constr & use from the NZ] or ii 2. =Why? how comes it? (Sc. Lan Cor) e.g. `How didn't you tell'ni would come?' (Pen). Cf OED adv. 1.c. Obsolete pregnant use = How is it that? How comes it that? Why? Last quot. 1611 Bible `How said thou, She is my sister?' cf 4 interject (esp US) =What? What! [(esp. ## humpback whale
 
 <i>n.</i> [aka hump back, hump-backed; incl NZ humpback, otherwise doubt NZ specificity]

>  They grow about 50 feet in length, and are quite slender, only having about half to one-third of the diameter of, say, a hump-backed whale. <i>(Jul 7, 1930,Evening Post,9</i>)

>  The agreement follows, on the whole, familiar lines, and under it it will not be lawful to take .. humpback whales of less than 35ft ... <i>(Jun 10, 1937,Evening Post,9</i>)

>  Tory Channel whalers struck a big humpback whale the other week, which rushed the boat and stove in three planks. <i>(Jul 8, 1896,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  At about two o'clock in the afternoon they were about a mile outside when they noticed a big humpback spouting not far away from them. <i>(Jun 26, 1913,Colonist (Nelson),2</i>)

>  News from the whaler Splendid, now at Friendly islands, says that she has taken five humpback whales in less than five weeks. <i>(Oct 4, 1881,Bay of Plenty Times,3</i>)

>  <b>McNAB</b> 5 boats in chased a humpback <i>(1913,Old Whaling Days,453</i>) [NOTES: 1836 Aug 7 Capt. Joy <i> Mary Mitchell </i> log in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 453]

>  MEGAPTERA NOVE-ZEALANDiAE. The New Zealand Humpback. <i>(1875,TrNZi,7/255</i>) [NOTES: (Hector)]

>  The humpback (<i> Megaptera nodosa </i>) is quite the most common of whales inhabiting the New Zealand seas: indeed, it is found plentifully in all portions of the world. <i>(1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/132</i>) [NOTES: (Oliver)]

>  The [whales] most commonly known to Tory Channel whalers are the "hump back." <i>(Apr 29, 1924,Otago Witness,71</i>)



## humpie
 
 <i>n.</i> a humpback whale

>  All binoculars are on the whale. "Something odd about that spout," says Johnnie, once a gunner like his brother. "it's not a humpie," says Joe. <i>(Aug 7, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28</i>)

>  <b>GRADY</b> ] Humpies - Humpback whales. A species of whalebone or baleen whale, the Megaptera longimana. it is distinguishable by its low rounded dorsal fin and its humps. <i>(1982,Perano Whalers,227</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (later) a rough shack

>  [Gum-fields] seated on an empty Kerosene-case outside his bark humpy, a man was sorting and scraping....gum. <i>(1906,Red Funnel,1/1/42</i>)

>  <b>ADAMS</b> We'll run up a sort of `humpy' for the ladies tomorrow [wrecked on desert island] <i>(1915,Grocer Greatheart,73</i>)

>  i gaze on the moon through the holes in the roof,/ Which shows that the `humpie' is not weatherproof/ ... some calls it a `lean-to', a `humpie', a `shack'.... <i>(1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,123</i>)

>  ~ n. a native's hut; a settler's house if small all primitive. [corrupt. fr. Maori compi, a hut] [incorrect HWO] <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,6</i>)

>  <b>RAWLiNSON</b> Like a hermit crab among the winding roots,/ his humpy's two shaky walls of tin/ propped between the rockface and a sack,/ <i>(1963,Of Clouds and Pebbles,12</i>)

>  humpy n. native hut, gunyah or mia-mia; by extension, any primitive dwelling [Abo.]. <i>(1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),10</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>GUTHRiE-SMiTH</b> the perturbed bird [snipe] would merely emerge with full spread pinions from its isolated humpie of manuka. <i>(1936,NZ Naturalist,186</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> [ca1985 Nov 21 Nicholas Ransom A small crib-room (q.v.) at the Tiwai Aluminium Smelter, Invercargill, to accommodate four persons]

>  <b>ADCOCK104</b> ... had his own quarters, the two-roomed shop ... The humpy, as we called it, was lighted only by a lamp ... <i>(1979,Butter in a Lordly Dish</i>)

>  <b>HALEY</b> Then again a modest bach or humpy on the edge of the mere would be ideal. <i>(1986,Settlement, The,60</i>)



## humping
 
 <i>n.</i> a lifting and (back-)carrying (of a load) [two of the three citations below are of the verb to hump]

>  [? ptc] ... take the lot by `humping' them out and home. <i>(Dec 19, 1870,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  it was too far from the river, he said, and would necessitate such an amount of `humping'. Bosh about humping! returned the majority. <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,1/117</i>)

>  There's also a competition to find the man/woman who can carry a dead pig the fastest over an obstacle course and if no pigs are shot then they'll end up humping a deer. <i>(Dec 28, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12</i>) [NOTES: Original in Weekend Sun, 25/10/2002]



## humpty
 
 <i>n.</i> the sack, dismissal

>  "Hey, they've given me the humpty," he told the <i>New Zealand Herald</i>. <i>(Sep 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> physical retaliation

>  When the All Blacks copped a walloping in Marseilles before Christmas, it was because Fabien Pelous, the Tricolore captain, decided that his side would revert to type, give it some old-fashioned humpty and to hell with the consequences. <i>(2001,Rugby 2001,36</i>)



## humpy
 
 <i>n.</i> a shack (See [also humpie](../A#also-humpie))

>  You couldn't tie women up with a length of chain and leave them out in the paddock, tied to a corrugated iron humpy for days at a time. They'd scream and cry, which would be damned irritating. <i>(Feb 14, 1999,Sunday Star Times,D2</i>)

>  When i was digging you had to get a licence, and that entitled you to dig anywhere and to put up a humpy (shack). <i>(Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,22</i>)

>  The 'humpy' - an Australian name for this basic type of building - was a small four-roomed house, each room running into the other with no passage. <i>(Apr 2004,NZ Memories,No. 47/53</i>)

## hundred
 
 <i>n.</i> a subdivision of agricultural land; Historical: a subdivision of some English, American and NZ counties or provinces [(Otago/Southland land subdivision) See Listener Nov. 18, 2000, p. 48.]

>  <b>WAKEFiELD</b> [`Terms of Purchase of Land in the Settlement of Otago' agreed on by the `Otago Association' and the Company] 11. Reservations to be made ... of the Sites of Villages and Towns ... in the Several Parishes and Hundreds ... <i>(1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,317</i>)

>  We hesitate not to confess ourselves admirers of the Hundred system and of agriculture rather then runholding, ... 1947 Note: The whole leader is an argument against declaring Hundreds before it becomes absolutely necessary, ... <i>(Dec 4, 1858,Otago Witness</i>) [NOTES: 1858 Dec 4 Otago Witness in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 10]

>  <b>RUTHERFORD</b> [The runanga] will bear the same relation to other political machinery ... as the township in the United States of America bears to the county and state organization, and ministers suggest the name of township as the most suitable English term for the community that will be represented by a single runanga. it will correspond with the division of hundreds proposed by his Excellency. [Grey's annotation] i should have preferred the term `hundred'. it is already in use here. The natives will make a strange word out of `township'. <i>(1949,Selected Documents,112e</i>) [NOTES: 1861 Nov 1 Memorandum by Ministers on Governor Grey's Proposed institutions for the Native Race in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 112e]

>  <b>RUTHERFORD</b> Each district [of the proposed Maori portion of the North island] to be divided into about six hundreds from the runangas of each of which will be selected two persons to represent such hundred in the runanga of the district, and to act as assessor or native magistrate. <i>(1949,Selected Documents,112A</i>) [NOTES: 1861 Nov 2 Sir George Grey Memorandum in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 112a]

>  <b>HEYWOOD</b> in Otago no land can be bought unless within the boundary of some hundred a sit is called - .... The Government of the Province proclaim hundreds when they deem necessary. <i>(1863,Vacation Tour at the Antipodes, A,224</i>)

>  .. as these runs are likely to be wanted for settlement, i should not recommend their being thrown into a gold field till after they have been thrown into Hundreds when the Waste Lands Board could refuse to sell any portion ... considered highly auriferous. <i>(Apr 20, 1869,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1869 May 20 letter in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 16]

>  The Provincial Government have the power of declaring any portion or the whole of a run into `hundreds' as they are called, the land in this hundred can be bought by any person at [pound]1 per acre for the cheapest price. <i>(Feb 9, 1873,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1873 Feb 9 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 173]

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> [in Otago] a `hundred' and the land is then opened up for sale at 1 [pound] per acre.... The purchases of land within a `hundred' have the exclusive privilege of depasturing stock upon the unsold lands within the `hundred' in proportion to their purchased property. A small fee or assessment of so much per head, is paid to the Government for this privilege. [Until the land is sold. All land unsold after a few years may be brought at ten shillings per acre] <i>(1874,Colonial Experiences,197</i>)

>  <b>HOCKEN</b> The old Otago Block had already been divided into Hundreds, at first three in number, but was now subdivided for greater convenience into eight. The first extended from the Heads to the Taieri river, ... Within these Hundreds the rural lands were open for sale at 10s. and acre, with the 40s. improvement conditions. Outside them were 600,000 acres, open for sale at 10s. an acre, in blocks of not less than 2000 acres, without the improvement clause. <i>(1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,167</i>)

>  <b>COWAN</b> Grey and his Ministers introduced also a system of local government; under this plan the Maori country was to be divided into districts and `hundreds', over each of which a Civil Commissioner was to be placed to grapple with the task of governing the natives in his zone of influence ... <i>(1922,NZ Wars, The,1/233</i>)

>  <b>AYSON</b> He had to find rent of ground to give him the right to run cattle on `the hundred,' and had to pay two and sixpence assessment a head to the Wardens to be spent on road-making. <i>(1937,Thomas,94</i>)

>  <b>WAiTE</b> Whatever were the ancient-English meanings in Otago [a `hundred'] came [in 1850s-60s] to signify run country surveyed and cut up for small settlement freeholds. And one can appreciate what the term meant to a runholder who had just got stocked up and his run working efficiently. <i>(1948,Pioneering in South Otago,38</i>)

>  <b>SCOTTER</b> in 1869, ... the administration of the hundreds was centralized in Dunedin (Times June 18, 1869). <i>(1948,Run, Estate and Farm,15</i>)

>  HUNDRED Under the old land-subdivision system in New Zealand, a subdivision of a County. Still used in parts of Southland in the place of Survey District. <i>(1952,NZ Forest Glossary</i>)

>  <b>ELDRED-GRiGG</b> The [Otago] provincial government also empowered itself to confiscate grants and create small farming settlements called 'hundreds'. <i>(1980,Southern Gentry,66</i>)

>  According to Dr Ray Hargreaves.. the hundred line road relates to the subdivision of land in the 19th century, and was borrowed from an English tradition... "On payment of an annual license fee, landowners within a hundred had the privilege of running stock on the unsold portions. The first three hundreds for Otago were proclaimed in October, 1854." <i>(Nov 18, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48</i>)



## hundred-inch country
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a land area with a heavy rainfall and leaching, requiring particular pasture management.

>  We call this part of Taranaki the '100-inch country.' in the 100-inch country the sooner the land is converted from its rough state into permanent pasture the better ... Another point discovered by the settlers of the 100-inch country was the necessity for heavy liming. <i>(May 21, 1942,NZ Farmer,16</i>)

## hungahunga
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>POLACK</b> One house contained some tons of hungahunga [a's-acute], or silken flax; the others with muka maori [o-diaresis], or common native flax. <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),1/140</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> The flax (<i>korari</i>,) forming the dresses is of two or [176] three kinds; the most coarse, called muka, is employed for working the common garment (<i>kakaou</i>[a1-acute] <i>maori</i>[a-acute].) This flax is also made use of for laying up ropes, lines, &c. The superior dress called Kaitaka[a2-a3-acute], is made from silken flax, (<i>hunga hunga</i>[as-acute].) <i>(1849,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/175</i>)

>  <b>LiNDSAY</b> in Otago the general name of the [flax] plant, as a whole, is `Korari,' - or as metamorphosed by the settler, pronounced and spelt `Koura<i>d</i>i,' [a-macron] or `Cora<i>d</i>i' [a-macron]. The same term is applied in the North island equally to the whole plant, and to the dried flower-stem when cut for rafts or other purposes; or exclusively to the flower-stalk. in the North [83] island, the Flax-plant is also known as `Harakeke,' or `Herekiakia,' - its usual name there. ... The lower part of the flower-stem is `Kaikaha;' the outer part of the leaf `Parakoka;' [a1, o-macron] the refuse of the leaf `Hunga-hunga;' the flax, dressed or not, or scraped fibre, manufactured from the leaf, `Whitau,' or `Muka.' <i>(1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,82</i>)



## hungerfine
 
 <i>n.</i> ultra fine wool induced by starvation [(woolgrowers')]

>  Hungerfine: Ultra fine wool induced by starvation. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,56</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of wool] fine and weak due to drought or a dietary deficiency.

>  <b>COOP</b> Since the wool at the break is not only weaker but is also finer ('hunger fine') the finest part of the staple comes at the ends instead of the middle of the staple. <i>(1950,Shearing Ewes before Lambing,25</i>)

>  Neither group grew good fine wool, much was 'hunger fine' and break was a serious fault. <i>(Mar 23, 1967,NZ Farmer,25</i>)

>  More hungerfine wool will be around in the Canterbury region and this will be something to watch for in the new season. The drought will make the wool hungerfine and this should be kept separate. [hunger fine] <i>(1985,NZ Shearer,1 2 Autumn/Winter 48</i>) [NOTES: ??NZ Shearer 1 2 Autumn/Winter 48]

>  <b>MAF</b> Hungerfine: ultra fine wool induced by starvation. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,56</i>)



## hungry
 
 <i>adj.</i> of land, soil, in poor condition, needing much fertiliser [ca1920 W.H.B. Orsman. -->(country)]

>  <b>BEATTiE</b> Just where Kingston Crossing is now the country was of such a poor hungry type that it was popularly called Starvation Flat. <i>(1947,Pioneer Recollections,39,1956 ed.</i>)

>  <b>CRUMP</b> ...into the headwaters of the Maunganuiohau River, which was famous as one of the hungriest areas on the lake block <i>(1960,Good Keen Man, A</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> also hungry-looking, of quartz or other potentially auriferous material, non-auriferous. [(goldfields)]

>  Nevertheless, a glance will convince the experienced miner that [the reef] is free from the peculiar appearance there is about non-auriferous quartz, which is denominated by miners as `hungry-looking stuff' <i>(1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,78</i>)

>  At the eastern face ... the good looking quartz is only from 5' to 12' in thickness, the remainder being hungry-looking. <i>(1875,AJHR,3/39</i>) [NOTES: Report Goldfields]



 
 <i>adj.</i> mean, niggardly [often in phr. hungry for money (greedy)]

>  <b>WHEELER</b> Doug still remembers the hungry stations where they ate old ewe, potatoes, rice pudding and, at the weekend, one pound of `brownie' per man. ... The boss said `brownie' was cake. We knew it only as bread dyed with bullocky's joy (treacle), and sparingly dotted with currants. <i>(1973,Historic Sheep Stations Ni,97</i>)

>  hungry ... 5. Austral. & N.Z. greedy; mean. 6. N.Z. (of timber) dry and bare. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,546</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 239]]



 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of land] malnourished and with a thin sole of grass.

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> The toughest stretch of our trip was winding our weary way home over the then hungry Canterbury plains. <i>(1962,Life's Roundabout, A,22</i>)

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> .. a poor hungry flat <i>(1974,Kingdom in the Hills,59</i>)

>  But it [light land] is very 'hungry' - that is, it consumes humus and other manures quickly. <i>(Mar 20, 1933,NZ Journal of Agriculture,182</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>adj.</i>

>  The hungry wool from poorly reared sheep, which carry very light fleeces, may appeal to him [the American buyer]. <i>(Jun 15, 1911,NZ Journal of Agriculture,349</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>adj.</i>

>  Barren Reefs, or Buck Reefs. ... in Otago they consist of very wide, massive, bold outcrops of `hungry' glassy quartz ... <i>(1908,TrNZi,41/81</i>) [NOTES: Finlayson]

>  Small pieces of quartz are included in the conglomorate bands which have already been described, but such as were seen by the writer of this report are of a decidedly `hungry' appearance. <i>(1910,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No 9 (N.S.): 46</i>) [NOTES: (Adams Raukumara, Poverty Bay)]

>  hungry a. of gold ore, unpromising. <i>(1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,6</i>)

>  <b>SUTHERLAND</b> it was encouraging to think of Bluey's nugget when working a block of `hungry' wash. <i>(1953,Golden Bush, The,63,1963 ed.</i>)

>  <b>McARA</b> it may have been that the white `hungry' appearance of much of the quartz on the surface discouraged earlier prospectors and they did not bother to test it by `dollying' and washing a few samples. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,29</i>)

>  <b>NOLAN</b> Hungry: of quartz or a mining site, barren or barely payable. <i>(1983,Gold Fossicker's Handbook,112</i>)

## hunt
 
 <i>n.</i> the ability of a dog to drive or hunt stock away from the handler; also to back on command while doing this. [(farming)]

>  Hunt: Ability of a dog to drive or hunt stock away from the handler, also to back on command while doing this. it can do a `straight' or `zig-zag' hunt. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,24</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> hunt off, get rid of.

>  25th - Loafer called; dirty loafer, hunted him; found my largest apple had fallen off the tree. <i>(Oct 25, 1904,NZ illustrated Magazine</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i>

>  ... while in the act of hunting a dog for the sheep a kea flew down to the back of a sheep ... <i>(1907,TrNZi,39/284</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> to drive (sheep) away from the shepherd, or from a given spot.

>  <b>McNAUGHTON</b> Mike stopped hunting them [sc. sheep] up [the race] and shouted to Legge, `When are you going to start drafting? ...' <i>(1970,Tat,25</i>)

>  <b>HARPER</b> Viper had turned her mob neatly over to Rough, who was hunting them away down the mountainside <i>(1934,Windy island,232</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>ACLAND</b> To hunt sheep off the higher parts of their winter country onto lower, safer [land] when snow is expected; e.g., `We hunted down every day for a week, but no snow came.' This is a very common expression in the Lakes district of Otago. i cannot remember hearing it in Canterbury, though the job is done often enough. <i>(1930,Early Canterbury Runs</i>) [NOTES: [1918]]

>  Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. <i>(Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>LiLiCO</b> [The dogs] would head, lead, hunt away, force and back. <i>(1934,Sheep Dog Memoirs,27</i>)

>  <b>HARTLEY</b> i taught him to hunt correctly and to back sheep and finally disposed of him for [pounds]22. <i>(1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,2</i>)

>  <b>McNAUGHTON</b> He could hunt a mob away, as well as pull, and he was also a champion yard dog, barking when commanded. <i>(1970,Tat,101</i>)

>  <b>ANDERSON</b> in April 1921 Ron was taken out to help with the autumn muster. One of the musterers ... gave him his first dog ... who would hunt as well as head. Davis also gave him a stout mustering-stick and showed him how to make the best use of it when sidling across a steep face. <i>(1981,Both Sides of the River,78</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) [sheepdogs] to drive sheep in a particular direction [often towards gateways or yards.]

>  Handy - a dog that heads a bit, hunts with a bit of noise and possibly backs as well. <i>(Oct 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,24</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> Hunting sheep is all about shepherding, not chasing, and can't be carried out at pace. <i>(1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,72</i>)

>  He is well bred, very forceful and will head, hunt and back. <i>(Jul 8, 1971,NZ Farmer,102</i>)

>  <b>KERR</b> Sheep - it is in their nature to be inconvenient - are invariably over or down or up there, and shepherds want them somewhere else. They must be hunted to that place, in dog trials off the flat and up the hill in the Straight Hunt. The ZigZag uses three sets of two poles to represent such obstacles and the dog must hunt the sheep left, then right, then left through them. <i>(2000,High Times in the High Country,136</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>v.</i> to move sheep forward or on; to use (a dog) as a huntaway. [1930 Acland.]

>  <b>STRONACH`</b> The next day we spent hunting the sheep on towards Boundary Creek, which runs into the Saxon, and the day after that we moved [15] camp to the Boundary Gully camp, and pushed all the sheep across the creek. <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,14</i>)

>  <b>McNAUGHTON</b> `You go ahead and take the gate, and i'll hunt them up the race,' Mike said. ... `You're hunting them through too fast!' Legge shouted back. `Give a man a fair go, can't you!' [26] Legge and Ustice hunted the sheep forward, and they ran nicely for a while. <i>(1970,Tat,25</i>)



## hunt back
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) to drive stock from former grazing areas [especially from high summer country.] (See [hunt down](../H#hunt-down))

>  <b>CRESSWELL</b> Every day i walked the ridges and hunted back sheep trying to make their way up to the high country. <i>(1942,Early NZ Families,158</i>)

>  <b>MACGREGOR</b> He was boundary keeping while doing a little fencing , and every day he had to hunt the sheep back out of the snow country. <i>(1980,Dog's Life, A,40</i>)

## hunt course
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a dog trial competition course for huntaway dogs.

>  Studying the country is just as important on hunt courses. <i>(1991,Constitution of NZ Dog Trial Assoc,4B</i>)

## hunt down
 
 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [high country farming] [see hunt back] to move sheep from the tops or basins to a lower area [for tupping or when snow threatens.]

>  Hunt down, to hunt the sheep off the higher parts of their winter country on to lower, safer spurs when snow is expected. e.g. 'We hunted down every day for a week but no snow came.' <i>(Oct 28, 1933,Press, The  (Acland Glossary),17</i>)

>  <b>MCKENZiE</b> it [the work] might be mustering, eye clipping, hunting down or even snow raking. <i>(1951,Wakatipu Pioneers,111</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> it so happened that that day i was given a job 'hunting down' a block called Plenty. i had to ... hunt them down to safer levels. <i>(1964,Straggle Muster,29</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> Hunt down: to hunt sheep out of the high basins and spurs and down to lower country. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,44</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i> [(station)]

>  Hunt down. To hunt the sheep off the higher parts of their winter country on to lower, safer spurs when snow is expected, e.g., `We hunted down every day for a week, but no snow came.' This is a very common expression in the Lakes district of Otago. i cannot remember hearing it in Canterbury, though the job is done often enough. (C,1918) <i>(Oct 28, 1933,Press, The,17</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>NEWTO</b> Hunting down: Where sheep are wintered on high unfenced country subject to snow it is a common practice to keep them hunted down from the higher, more dangerous snow levels. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,188</i>)

>  <b>Masters</b> it was built to house the hunter shepherd, whose job it was to keep sheep from straying over the unfenced Kereru boundary, and on to the Ruahine tops, and hunt down the wild dogs and pigs that infested the area. <i>(1960,Back-Country Tales,103</i>)
