## huntaway
 
 <i>n.</i> a dog that barks on command, trained to control sheep; a noisy sheepdog trained to drive sheep forward, away from the musterer; a special type of NZ sheep dog used for mustering; driving and backing dog that barks on command; see also Nelson huntaway. [(farming)]

>  The affable, witty, almost Bertie Wooster-like character, Terrence, works a restaurant with all the skill of a huntaway at a dog trial. <i>(Jul 10, 2004,Dominion Post,E8</i>)

>  A huntaway should be a free-running dog, noisy, and under good command, and should lose points for not taking directions readily, insufficient noise, being too rash or too slow, and not keeping the sheep on a good course. <i>(Sep 11, 1912,Otago Witness,35</i>)

>  <b>CARR</b> A new hand ... is wise investing in a good huntaway or a heading dog. He can practice [sic] on the `killers' i.e. the sheep kept handy for station use, or better still, a good noisy yard dog, as all station hands are liable to be called upon to assist in drafting, etc. <i>(1913,Country Work,33</i>)

>  Huntaway.A dog whose work is to drive sheep forward when mustering. As a verb the word is used in two sense, illustrated in the sentences: `That dog hunts away well' and `i hunt away with that dog.' (C.) <i>(Oct 28, 1933,Press, The,17</i>)

>  Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.) <i>(Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>LiLiCO</b> So far as i have heard and read, there is no other part of the world which has strains of natural huntaways, so we must accept the idea that huntaways are entirely a New Zealand product. <i>(1934,Sheep Dog Memoirs,26</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> There are breeds [of dog] for the varying types of [mustering] work,. ie, huntaways and heading dogs. The former are noisy dogs, and as the name implies, hunt sheep away, barking freely. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,13</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> HUNTAWAY: A noisy dog whose natural instinct is to hunt or chase sheep away. On account of their noise they are used for forcing mobs, work in the drafting yards, and for clearing or hunting' sheep off tracts of country. <i>(1949,High Country Days,195,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> So the shepherds soon bred dogs which had more the characteristics of the Old English sheepdogs - bouncing barking dogs which ... drive ... sheep ... They called them huntaways and this word is now so well known in New Zealand that it is part of the language. <i>(1951,High Country,5</i>)

>  <b>STRONACH</b> heading dog, no decent handy dog, and a rough assortment of huntaways. <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,15</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> He used his dogs for both rabbiting and sheep work, but only Nell, the huntaway, would have anything to do with pigs; and all she would ever do, was bail and keep her distance. <i>(1960,Back-Country Tales,159</i>)

>  <b>SHARPE</b> A sheepdog is either a huntaway, a heading dog, or a handy dog. <i>(1962,Country Occasions,97</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> HUNTAWAY: A noisy dog whose natural instinct is to hunt or chase sheep away. On account of their noise they are used for forcing mobs, work in the drafting yards, and for cleaning or `hunting' sheep off tracts of country. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,187</i>)

>  <b>McLiNTOCK</b> The huntaway sheep dog is a New Zealand development. Original imported strains were all heading dogs whose instinctive method was to head the sheep and, working silently, to pull them back to their masters. Early New Zealand shepherds, however, needed the occasional noisy dog which could flush sheep from cover on rough country. ... Huntaway: A noisy dog, whose natural instinct is to hunt or chase sheep away. On account of their noise, they are used for forcing mobs, work in the sheep yards, and for clearing or hunting sheep off tracts of country. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/493</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> Huntaway: A dog which drives sheep away, barking on command - or more frequenty at its own pleasure. <i>(1970,Glorious Morning,253</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> Huntaway: A noisy dog used for driving the sheep away from the musterer. <i>(1972,Mountain World,310</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> huntaway: A huntaway is a NOiSY (barking) WORKiNG DOG used to drive sheep, cattle or recently, deer to new paddocks. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,54</i>)

>  Huntaway: Special type of New Zealand dog used for mustering. A driving and backing dog that barks on command. <i>(1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,24</i>)

>  huntaway n. N.Z. a dog trained to drive sheep at a long distance from the shepherd. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,546</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 366; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 239]]

>  <b>RENNiE</b> The Beardie was developed as a barking dog because in some parts of Scotland, particularly in the Western Highlands, much of the ground is covered with bracken, which combined with the deep gullies known as corries, makes it impossible for a heading dog to see his sheep. Here the shepherd has to get out above the sheep and more or less chase them out of the thick cover. These dogs were known as hunters, and it is presumably an adaptation of this name which led to the designation, huntaway. At the turn of the century there were four well known strains of huntaways about North Canterbury and Marlborough - the Clown, Rag, Borderglen's Rose and Pollock's Old Clyde breeds. Of these the Clown strain certainly had Beardie blood, believed to have been started with a half Beardie brought out from Scotland. <i>(1985,Working Dogs,12</i>)

>  <b>HARTLEY</b> The fact that the dog learned the command that denoted he was to lead, automatically placed him in position to take up huntaway work. <i>(1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,36</i>)

>  <b>McLiNTOCK</b> The huntaway sheep dog is a New Zealand development. [ca1901] <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/493</i>)

>  Good stock dogs those Labs, great bark. They bred them into huntaways in the old days you know, for the bark. <i>(2003,Huia 5: Contemp. Maori Fiction,238</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Maid, although by a huntaway dog, would catch sheep anywhere on the hill. <i>(1996,Boss's Story, The,141</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> The sooler is another rough and tough dog of the huntaway type and is renowned for his ability to shift even the most stubborn of sheep. <i>(1967,Return to Open Country,38</i>)

>  The KZ7 team.. could improve its status with the locals by using a doggie mascot which is more authentically kiwi - a huntaway, perhaps, or a pig dog. <i>(Dec 15, 1991,Dominion Sunday Times,10</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a NZ-bred barking sheepdog that shepherds, gathers and hunts sheep towards gateways or yards.

>  <b>LiLiCO</b> .. the huntaways are entirely a New Zealand product. <i>(1934,Sheep Dog Memoirs,26</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Huntaway: A noisy dog whose instinct is to hunt or chase sheep away. <i>(1949,High Country Days,195</i>)

>  <b>KERR</b> Huntaways or barking dogs work with noise: chasing, blocking and pushing to herd sheep into position. <i>(2000,High Times in the High Country,135</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> The huntaway is 100 per cent New Zealand bred .. the huntaway was developed because our early musterers and runholders saw the benefits of properly applied noise. <i>(1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,73</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

>  <b>McLiNTOCK</b> Huntaway. in both huntaway classes three sheep are set loose at the foot of the hill. While the shepherd remains at the bottom, his dog, working and barking to command, hunts the sheep upwards on a defined line away from his master. in the zig-zag hunt, the sheep are directed through three sets of flags 1 chain apart and spaced equally up the hill on a zig-zag course of approximately 440 yards. The course for the straight hunt is about the same length, from the foot of the hill up to and through a set of flags 1 chain apart. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/493</i>)



 
<b>3</b> <i>n.</i>

>  <b>McGiLL</b> huntaway mustering dog; boulder in upper South island rolled down steep slopes with same mustering purpose. [Jim Henderson] <i>(1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,59</i>)

## hurdy-gurdy
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>REED</b> `hurdy-gurdy' [is a hand gum-washing machine, turned by a handle] -->[See also Reed Story of Kauri Gum] <i>(1948,Gumdigger, The,56</i>)

>  <b>REED</b> The machine age on the gumfield appears to have been heralded as early as 1915 when an ingenious digger, whose name has unfortunately been forgotten, introduced what came to be known as the `hurdy-gurdy' or `gurdy.' ... [83] in its simplest form it was a tub, or a section of a small galvanised iron tank, the bottom perforated with small holes. in the centre stood a strong, revolving, upright shaft, to the lower part of which was attached a wooden paddle, extending on both sides of the shaft, almost to the sides of the tank. The top of the revolving shaft was fitted with a horizontal handle, enabling the paddle to be swung to and fro in a half-circle. This simple machine was usually operated by two men; a supply of gum-bearing dirt having been put into the tank, buckets of water were thrown in by one man while the other vigorously turned the shaft handle this way and that, stirring up the soil while the muddy water flowed out through the perforations. <i>(1972,Gumdiggers, The,82</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> a piano

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> (esp.something which revolves). [ca1920 J. Morrison a merry-go-round]

## hydraulic deal
 
 <i>n.</i> (hire purchase)

>  A HiGH COURT jury was told by Crown counsel Justin Smith in Wellington yesterday of a hire purchase `hydraulic deal' - a transaction, in which a hire purchase agreement stated a deposit had been paid whereas, in fact, it had not. ... Mr Smith said that during the trial the jury would hear about what was known colloquially as a `hydraulic deal'. This was a situation where there was a deal in which a dealer intended to sell a truck for, say, $50,000 and required a deposit of $10,000 by any hire purchaser. in the case of a $50,000 truck (a hypothetical example) the dealer knew the hire purchase company was going to have reservations about financing the full $50,000. `So the dealer draws up a hire purchase agreement anyway. The real price is still $50,000. But on the agreement the dealer said he had received the sum of $10,000 by way of deposit.' Mr Smith said that if a hire purchase company accepted the assignment of the agreement the dealer got his money in full and the customer got his truck (then claimed to be worth $60,000) without having to pay a deposit. <i>(Apr 12, 1985,Evening Post</i>) [NOTES: 1985? Apr? c12-24 Dom ?Evening Post - check date]
